review.text: - The article deals with a contingent and very relevant problem, and includes both a national diagnosis of the use of good practices and a solution (concrete good practices). - The language is adequate. - The article feels like the concatenation of three different articles: (1) results of a survey, (2) good security practices, (3) incorporation of good practices - The order of the sections would be better if it reflects this order (the revised version is #2, # 1, #3).- The article has no validation of any kind, not even by expert evaluation.

The article presents practical recommendations for developing secure software. Recommended best practices for developing software that is proactive against attacks are described, and a cost analysis of these practices in software development is performed. All based on in a review of practices proposed in the bibliography and its contrast with data obtained from a survey in companies. Finally, a guide is recommended. It would be ideal to apply the proposed guide to companies not involved in the survey that served to originate it in order to be able to evaluate their effectiveness independently.

- The topic is very interesting and a guide to incorporate security practices can be very helpful. - The presentation (description, stage and use) of the 9 practices for the development of secure software. - The “state development of software in Chile” (as indicated in his paper) cannot be achieved with only 22 surveys out of a total of 50. - It presents nine tables that correspond to the practices for the development of secure software, but the guide presents 10 practices. Explain why? - I suggest improving the guide, the greatest contribution is in the sequence of incorporation that it proposes. In addition, it should not explain the practice in Observations or differentiate it from other practices in that column, but rather it should give suggestions for how to apply it - In the text it indicates

Which ones are they or did I not read correctly? - According to the format, put at least 5 keywords - I suggest mentioning the practices before showing c each table. - Some references are incomplete, for example, missing year in reference 17, missing year and type of event in reference 11, missing editorial in reference 19 (is it a book?) - Some titles have a comma inside the quotes, example, reference 1

An experience of using ICT for academic collaboration is explained in an orderly and didactic way. The originality of the work is not its strong dimension, see long-standing works such as Gorton et al. (1997) and current ones such as Lanunile et al.(2010).However, the relevance of the topic as a reference pattern in activities related to scientific theses, associated with its good presentation, make it a contribution.It is suggested, with a view to publication in a journal, that it be compare the efficiency and effectiveness of the activities without the support of these tools versus the current reality (with tools) Examples of possible questions to answer from this exploratory analysis: What are the main activities where the use of collaborative tools is key? What changes in the design of these tools should be developed in the future Are there student/academic profiles that are more conducive to the adoption of these platforms References: Gorton, I., Haw Ryszkiewycz, I., and Ragoonaden, K. 1997. Collaborative tools and processes to support software engineering shift work. BT Technology Journal 15, 3 (Jul. 1997), 189-198. Filippo Lanubile, Christof Ebert, Rafael Prikladnicki, Aurora Vizcaino, "Collaboration Tools for Global Software Engineering," IEEE Software, vol. 27, no. 2, p. 52-55, Mar./Apr. 2010.

The authors describe a methodology to collaboratively develop theses and reports using technologies that are commonly used in software development. They also describe specific tools and their benefits, such as Latex and Git. Finally, propose a workflow for the development of projects of this nature.The main value of the article lies in the application of knowledge that students already dominate -that is, software development techniques and tools- to a different problem as is the case of the theses and memoirs. All this, with the aim of making the process more efficient. 1.- The emphasis of the article is the solution without making a detailed analysis of the problem that it is intended to solve. In other words, there are no answers to the following questions: a.- What exactly is the problem? b.- What impacts does this problem generate? c.- Why is it important to solve the problem? d.- What solutions have been implemented? or to date? e.- What advantages does the proposed solution have with respect to the previous ones? 2.- In my opinion, the article should emphasize more the methodology and workflow. For example, adding a diagram -using a visual language- that allows, on the one hand, to understand the general thesis development process and, on the other, to distinguish the roles, activities and associated technologies in each phase of the report. 3.- Some aspects of the language and the rigor of certain statements must be taken care of, such as: "(given the rather atrocious spelling enjoyed by engineers)". Do the authors have any empirical support to support this claim? Is it necessary to resort to such prosaic language to justify the convenience of using a certain technological tool? By the way, I recommend reviewing the expressions: "it is not public" (point 3.1) and "Having access directly..." (point 3.2)

This paper proposes a new approach based on [25] to support the SR recommendation by evolving user feature weights through two approaches using genetic algorithms. The paper seems technically correct and the proposal presents robust results according to what is presented in the document The document has a series of apparently typographical errors that lead to confusion, where the names of variables, abbreviations or presentation format of subscript variables, etc. are changed. For example: equation 2, function w, abbreviation CF, figure 3, figure 6. Apparently the approach uses only part of the DB for efficiency reasons, it would be nice to use some indexing technique to support this process.

This paper aims to show new deployment alternative for recommender systems. To this end, the authors use two variations CHC genetic algorithm. - It's a good job. - It is clear and very detailed. - There are inconsistencies in the notation should be improved.The formula (7) has a notation different from the rest of the equations.- On the same point, the figure (3) refers to "profile", "weights", "euclidian\
neighbourhood"; these words aren't related with the text. - I think that the results shown in graphs would be more useful if they are shown in tables.

review.remarks: very good job
review.text: Novel quantum encryption modeling work being done I don't see negatives

This paper involves the development of an application that simulates the BB84 protocol, an orderly work is appreciated and without a doubt the understanding of some concepts of quantum physics that support quantum cryptography such as the no-cloning theorem and the principle of superposition and interweaving is a task that has its merits, in addition, the use of software engineering in the construction of the application is appreciated, which is a very positive aspect, since generally when software creation is involved in areas of frontier knowledge, code-and-fix is used, with all the disadvantages that this entails. I believe that this manuscript should be directed to the area of cryptography and security, in my specialty, which is computing in distributed environments, I do not see significant relevance and contribution of the manuscript, using RMI in my opinion is not a contribution per se, since RMI is easy to use if JAVA is handled, however, it is not interoperable since ue does not support other programming languages, in addition, the RMI-based systems as they grow have a performance problem, the more they grow the slower they become, on the other hand, according to some purists a client / server system is not a distributed system According to others, the client/server case is the most basic case of distributed computing. In short, speaking strictly from the area of distributed computing, I do not see relevance in this area of this manuscript. However, it seems to me that in another area the paper could be pertinent, since it is an orderly, clear and well-written work. I am not an expert in the area of cryptography, but a few years ago I once heard an Englishman talk about quantum cryptography in a seminar and he mentioned a large number of simulators and applications, he even said that he had applications that already used quantum cryptography among several kilometers through fiber optics, so I think it is best to evaluate this manuscript in that area and not in the area of grid/distributed systems, because in this area the paper, in my opinion, does not have original aspects, since it uses trivial aspects of client/server principles. As I have said before, the paper has more issues of quantum physics and cryptography than distributed computing, for which abstracting myself from the area that concerns me, I see the use of a distributed environment technology used as a client/server, not interoperable and with scalability restrictions. A positive aspect in the paper is that the use of software engineering is appreciated. Regarding the area of grid computing and distributed systems, the manuscript does not contain relevant aspects, it uses RMI to implement a client/server system, however, RMI is easy to use and as a well-known paradigm in computing, performance is opposed to ease of use, RMI does not escape that, because it is easy to use, but it does not have scalability. The document is well presented, perhaps table 2 and table 3 would be better merged using rows as computer and in the columns the details of the network, especially if there is more than a client/server scheme, for example, a network distribution ring. quantum keys, with more than 2 computers involved. I think being introduced to the crypto and security area would be more pertinent.

Novel proposal. Well structured. Correctly written. I only suggest: Explain in more detail the trapezoidal function on page 2. Rewrite the paragraph before the trapezoidal function A(x). Enlarge the scheme of figure 1 Explain the proposed architecture shown in figure 2. Check the reference of Feng et al., which is reference 2 and in a paragraph of column 2 page 1 it is marked as reference 1. Article is not in the format requested by Infonor, for Please change to this format.

The topic is interesting and well structured when it comes to proposal design. The topic deals with an approach to improvement, however it only sets out an architecture proposal, focusing on design, and not indicates how this improvement will be evaluated or measured for the SDW, it is recommended to add metrics or other aspects for it It does not provide many details, it is recommended to increase the number of pages to improve this aspect There are not many bibliographic references to works or efforts related on the subject.
With a high technical profile, it is a contribution to the subject. Too concise, it could extend into the how (especially from the fuzzy contribution).

- Innovative proposal for the application of an industrial engineering methodology to the field of requirements engineering. - There is no unification of terms throughout the document, related to the requirements engineering phase: 'eduction', ' elicitation'... The same term should always be used - There is no evidence of how the gradual 'improvements' of the elicitation process are quantified, and the 'improvement' in the quality of the documentation... how do they measure this improvement? writing and spelling errors, particularly in the use of accents (tildes) and punctuation marks (use of commas and semicolons).The article proposes the use of a work philosophy from another area of engineering, to improve the quality levels of the requirements documents generated in a requirements elicitation process I consider that from the technical point of view it would be important that they support the analysis of the results that they propose in a quantified measurement or comparison, which e allows, through a more formal method than the descriptive one, to generate the conclusions of 'improvement' in the quality of the products associated with the requirements engineering process. There is no evidence of how they reach the conclusions generated, what are they based on to say that it is better or not, that it has fewer errors or not? It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering processes. Currently it contributes to reduce the crisis associated with this phase of development of software products. The organization of the document can be improved considerably. I consider that a large part of the article is dedicated to expressing the associated conceptual framework, and less to the application of the technique in the case study and the analysis of results, sections in which the proposal presented can be supported more. Likewise, there are spelling and writing errors that, if avoided, can add value to the presentation of the article.

Try to apply a new strategy to requirements management. The applicability of techniques from manufacturing processes to software processes is not supported or considered. Although it is true that there are authors such as Demming who suggest that it is possible to do so, There are other authors such as Sommerville who argue that due to the characteristics of software development, manufacturing process techniques are not applicable to software. The authors of this article do not provide support in relation to the validity of this aspect. The article begins by stating that the proposal is to improve the elicitation of requirements, however, then it follows that what is improved is the generation of the SRS. The elicitation and the generation of the requirements document are different aspects. In the case of experimentation that is presents, it is not seen anywhere that problems are solved neither in the eduction, nor in the generation of the SRS, they are rather problems of the implementation mentation. The errors detected are basic aspects that any programmer with a minimum of experience knows how to solve, without the need for the SRS to specify the type of minimum validations that must be carried out as part of the system tests. The proposal lacks practical guidelines to help in its application. How should these POKA-YOKE reviews be carried out? What aspects should you pay attention to? Are there artifacts to guide the review? There are editing errors in the text (repeated words) There are spelling problems (word stress)

Good practice to ensure quality in requirements elicitation - The abstract is poorly written, there should be no theoretical explanations - The translation of the abstract is lousy - The article is not written in the third person - The POKA YOKE Section should go before section VARIABILITY OF REQUIREMENTS AND COST OF QUALITY - There are several misspellings

review.remarks: I believe that an article by six researchers can contain clearer aspects of research. At this point in time, I believe that it has already been shown that an intelligent reading of process improvement methods and techniques allows for their understanding. Therefore, I consider that the article should be more specific in the presentation of these and develop more work on the proposal that they carry out in a special way.
review.text: The article details a requirements management proposal based on KAIZEN. The authors describe different methods and techniques to complement Kaizen I understand that the main contribution of this work is, according to the authors, to complement and improve Kaizen for elicitation and management of requirements. However, the authors of the article present only a theoretical construction of their proposal. I understand that the article still has work to develop, in order to validate the proposal. However, since it is an article developed by six researchers, I consider that should include more applicative aspects of the proposal.
Interesting work. Although the document shows a proposal, it would be interesting to show applications.

The paper describes an experience concerning the automated inspection of spectra for the Pipeline Hubble Legacy Archive Grism data. Comments: In the conclusions the authors say that "We have identified two classes of flawed spectra which were not picked up by the automatic classification because of their very small number of training samples. Per construction machine learning techniques can not classify such outliers." This sentence should be further explained. As Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman say in The Elements of Statistical Learning (see Chapter 7): "it is too difficult to give a general rule on how much training data is enough; among other things, this depends on the signal-to-noise ratio of the underlying function, and the complexity of the models being fit to the data. " So, by just saying that the number of training samples is small you do not provide enough information to decide whether machine learning techniques are adequate or not to solve a problem. Other minor comments: + If reference [2] has not yet been written or published it should be deleted from the paper. The dataset may be of scientific importance. It is mainly descriptive.

This manuscript addresses an interesting solution based in machine learning techniques to classify spectra legacy data of the Hubble Space Telescope in order to publish the results and "good" spectra in Internet to scientific community. The manuscript is well- written and results are robust. Experiment is sound and the manuscript seems acceptable in the current form. The work can be short, but very interesting to the Infonor and JCC community. The main problem of the paper is that it is difficult to compare results for the classifiers utilized.A confusion matrix and parameters for each classifier could clarify results.

This paper presents a tool (SAVE) for software architecture verification. SAVE performs a static check of rules associated with permitted and prohibited dependencies between elements of the design and the code, and allows to deliver a report on consistency between both levels regarding these rules. In general, the tool seems quite powerful for two reasons: the use of simple rules and the inclusion of pre-defined rule sets for widely used design patterns. This, in my opinion, is the most important difference with other similar frameworks. The wording is, in some places, unobjective. In particular, I would suggest avoiding excessive use of adjectives for which no supporting evidence is provided. For example, in several places I noticed the use of "powerful tool", "intuitive tool" or similar (not only referring to SAVE, but to other works.) In all these cases, an e clairvoyance that supports the use of these adjectives. Another detail that requires fixing is the title that appears in the PDF file: "Prediction of behavior dynamics...", which does not match the title of the paper. The authors probably used a template from a previous paper with that title.

The verification of the architecture of a software product can be a great contribution to its quality, therefore, any tool that facilitates this task is a contribution to software engineering. They present evidence of a previous review alternative or complementary methods and tools to the proposal. The descriptions presented are accompanied by explanatory examples. The role and interaction of the domain expert is not clear. In the initial sections it says that the tool performs static and dynamic analysis, however at the end of the article, in the identification of possible improvements of SAVE it is proposed to include dynamic analysis, which contradicts the initial statement The description of the tool's operation is not clear enough The quality of the figures is not adequate, for the size and resolution of the same ones it is not possible to appreciate the details well. The writing of the article can be improved. There are several sentences where connectors are missing, for example "In this section, we will see SAVE manages to recover existing dependencies in the source code...." Many errors in the accentuation of words.

Novel proposal, very valuable linking people from the business world, which allows the theory and proposals for software engineering to be tested in real environments. Well structured and very well written. I only suggest outlining the application activities of White Belt IR - SixSigma training and review minor drafting details.
Good practice for better quality in requirements engineering - There should be no theory in the abstract - There should be a case study to better see the application of the methodology

Interesting proposal in a software development environment that is quite poor in development methodological aspects. A bit of related work is missing or perhaps better discussed in the introduction with references to substantiate the interesting proposal. Check wording. It is not in the format requested by Infonor. It is suggested not to add links to web pages in the text of the article.

The authors have designed a methodology for developing software to support scientific research projects. They quite precisely identify the differences between developing research software and software for commercial purposes. They also propose a methodology following an approach of agile methods of software development. The proposal is in a design phase, has been prepared from interviews with potential users and is likely to be tested in future research. In my opinion, the article needs a section that gives account of the methodology that the authors followed to arrive at the proposal Reference is made to interviews with: "participants in this type of project", however, it is not reported how many people were consulted, how the interviewees were selected, what instruments were applied and how the data was analyzed.

I consider, first of all, that the field of development of the theme (software development in research environments...) does not "grant permission" to carry out this development in a more informal way (times, relaxation in versions, little documentation, etc.) 2nd, I don't see why only SCRUM is proposed, without making basic comparisons with the other "classic" exponents of agile methodologies (XP and FDD), which gives it a certain " lightness" to the initial analysis by the authors (no doubt it could go a little deeper, especially with XP).

review.remarks: This is an article that presents a new topic in the area of software engineering. I think it will be very interesting to learn about this project in the context of the JCCC.
review.text: This is an article that presents a novel topic in the area of Software Engineering. The article is very well documented and substantiated. The technologies used in the development of the prototype are of current interest. As the article describes, It is a first step in a line of research and the development of a prototype of a meta-case application. In this sense, it remains unclear what the current level of maturity is, both of the research and of the developed application.

This paper presents a software tool that is useful in the context of software engineering. The authors do a good job describing the technical details of the tool. However, there is little information about the novel aspects of the proposed tool, How does the proposal compare to other existing tools (if any)?
A very clear, precise and high-level work

The article presents the design of a prototype that implements a system for data acquisition through wireless mobile devices, applied to mining, specifically in the monitoring of particulate matter. The application of mobile technology to a specific problem of the Chilean mining industry, in addition the article describes in a very clear way the problem and the proposed prototype.The article is novel since it considers the use of computing (data processing) and applied mobile device technologies to a specific problem of the Chilean mining industry The problem, the presented technology (BUG) and the proposed prototype are clearly described The application of current mobile computing technologies in important industrial sectors of the country is relevant The main title and the abstract must be written in Spanish and English (they only come in Spanish). In addition, the article or displays a list of 29 references, but only references one (the first in the list). It even shows up in the PCFactory References, and it's not really clear why.

Consider the use of mobile technologies to incorporate in the measurement of particulate matter that exists inside a mine. It will be interesting to see the advantages and disadvantages of this application with other existing ones. It is a study only. There is not yet results.

review.remarks: This work has many inconsistencies.
review.text: An extensive work that is valued is appreciated, however several inconsistencies are observed throughout the work. It is observed on page 4 figure 1 the indication of a conceptual model being this of the snowflake type, however the correct thing would be to indicate that it is a logical design schema and not a DW conceptual design. In addition, a correct conceptual schema should not indicate the type of data. Also in this aspect, reference is made to a star schema bibliography. Research on models was lacking concepts for DW to avoid the above A lot of redundancy in technical problems that should not be of importance for the article There is talk of business intelligence but in a strict sense if business intelligence is applied an

analyst is needed who is capable of of making decisions with the trends found in the study, which is not presented in the article.References of related works are missing, since only books are referenced . A review of related works would have been very useful in order to better structure the article. There are methodologies to outline the ETL process that would have allowed improving this aspect described in the article.

review.remarks: NOTE: The first version of this review was for another article.
review.text: The article presents the process of building a data warehouse to implement OLAP on data on the exploitation of marine resources off the coast of Chile. The problem is clearly defined and has a relevant practical application for the country. The work presented corresponds to a very complete and thoroughly documented use case of well-known data mining techniques The ABSTRACT should be edited to represent an appropriate and readable translation of the ABSTRACT The original contribution of the paper is not evident The original conclusions of the article they say related to the domain of the application (statistics of exploitation of marine resources) and not with topics relevant to the conference. The missing information in the bibliography should be completed.

review.remarks: Although the article follows a standard structure, it has some formatting problems that need to be corrected.
review.text: The article presents the development of a solution to the problem of analyzing trends in the landing of marine species on the Chilean coastline, using business intelligence tools. a) aspects of form 1. the English version of the title and the abstract of the article contains grammatical, editorial, and style errors 2. Use of capital letters: chile --> Chile National Fisheries Service --> National Fisheries Service kettle --> Kettle table 1 --> Table 1 api --> API etc. 3. Figure 2 is not referenced This figure shows --> Figure 10 shows 4. paragraph after Figure 1 is written in 1 column, must be in 2 columns 5. format does not fully match the Infonor format b) background aspects 1. The article does not report research results It is an application of BI techniques to provide support for online data analysis 2. It is weak in terms of background processes and techniques Although 12 references are listed, only 2 or 3 of them are cited repeatedly. There is no review of related works (cases of BI applications.) 3. Given the orientation of the article, the (potential) use of the results should be much more detailed. In this sense, there must be a greater and better interpretation/evaluation by the users of the information analyses.

This paper performs a categorization of ways to integrate business rules in a design using the aspect-oriented paradigm and proposes a documentation template for business rules based on this categorization. The paper provides useful information about the problem in particular, as well as a reasonable categorization of different aspects in this problem. It is a good starting point for an investigation in this line. Although the information provided in the paper is highly relevant for an investigation on this topic, it is insufficient to accept it as a complete and self-contained work. The reason is that the paper focuses on identifying problems and proposing an artifact (the template) that should solve these problems. However, it does not present evidence why this template is a good alternative to solve these problems. For this, the elements mentioned in the future work are required, specifically the specification form al and the automatic tool to create templates and map them to AOP. My suggestion is to wait until these elements are ready to complete this paper and send it to a new conference.

The work presents a viable alternative to solve the problem of changing business rules. It can be improved by adding a little more background to the topic of aspects, since prior knowledge of this topic is assumed, so the paper is not self-contained.

The work presents a methodology to address the complexity of implementing business rules without making changes to the base functionality of a system. It proposes a clear methodology based on documentation through templates to manage and analyze the impact of implementing business rules. a business rule via aspect orientation The reasons presented to indicate that the OA approach to encapsulate the connection between the business rules and the base functionality is not a trivial task, they are general and should be addressed in greater depth Does not present evidence that the use of the proposed templates concretely solve a problem. It is suggested to present a problem solved by means of the tool that is under development that automatically handles the templates. Failing that, demonstrate the application to a specific problem.

review.remarks: Review the English used in the article, there are errors that can be corrected for publication.
review.text: This is an article that presents an interesting diagnosis of the software development companies in Chile. They incorporate an initial statistical base that gives formality to the work carried out, specifically for the determination of the base sample for the development of the surveys. However, the statistical data of the results are not part of the work presented. Presentation of statistical results that validate the conclusions presented and the findings found, about the diagnosis. It is recommended that the authors continue in the work in order to incorporate the bases Trending statistics in companies in the sector in other countries Other recommendations: Exhaustive review of the English and particularly for the presentation of the article, the translation of this language should be carefully reviewed Particularly review the title, where there is an error in the first word.

The development of a prototype for an automatic software requirements assignment tool among developers is presented. This tool can be very useful for software development teams. It is about making a contribution through this tool to the quality of the developed products The heuristics used to assign requirements to the programmers are not explained A study of the existing requirements management tools is not presented, where it is shown that there are no alternative tools to the one presented And if there are alternatives, justify why to develop a new one The functionalities of the tool are not clearly explained There is no evidence of the improvement of the process by including this tool, it is only said in the conclusions that "the change in the quality of the process" The bibliographic references used are mostly web pages, a bibliographic review is not noted lyographic in specialized databases. The figures are not well distinguished. The bibliographical references do not comply with the established format. You must write in the third person.

- Novel requirements planning proposal for a software factory, as a contribution towards improving the quality of projects. - Although the title of the article is oriented towards 'requirements planning', this point it is only addressed again when they narrate how they implemented the prototype - They do not include a conceptual basis that allows supporting the role that requirements management plays in the software development process and particularly in the quality assurance of the process - It is not known evidences how with a contribution in the automatic planning of the requirements for the software factory, this will allow you to reduce your development times (estimated vs. real) and therefore ensure a higher quality - The relationship that exists between the proposal that it makes within the framework of CMMI. The article proposes a requirements planning model, supported by an automatic tool. The prototype that they propose is interesting nt and relevant. I think that the model and method that they propose associated with it, which is actually the real contribution of the authors, can be better organized. I consider that from the technical point of view it would be important that the analysis of the results that they propose with the case study of the bank, be done through an interpretation or quantitative comparison, which really shows that with this automatic planning the quality is really being improved. of the process and/or at least the estimation and actual execution of development times will be shorter, a scenario that, according to background information, has already been justified in its direct relationship with quality. It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering management processes. Currently, it would contribute to the reduction of time associated with this phase of software product development, and consequently with the quality of the process. Bearing in mind that Requirements Engineering has so many causes and problematic actions, which generate software crises and therefore an affectation in quality management, it remains an open question whether a contribution towards the 'planning' of the requirement really achieves a considerable effect, with respect to other causes or crucial points such as 'prioritization of requirements', validation and/or its traceability as such. The organization of the document can be improved in the following aspects: - Some of the figures that are included are not necessary, since they really do not provide anything additional to what is described in the text, and visually they do not say much. - In the 'APARD Design' section they mention many technical aspects characteristic of reference software factories, which do not give more weight to the intention of the article, nor are they giving really influential data for the application. - The quality of the figures can be optimized (mainly those that show the internal components of the algorithm and the actions of use of the system -profiles, since they are the ones that show the greatest contribution). - There are several drafting errors that should be reviewed (for example: the use of 'on the basis of' should be changed to 'based on'; 'is used', to 'is used'.. )

- The APARD tool - The topic associated with requirements and software factory is interesting - The practical case that considers the use of APARD with its advantages and limitations is not detailed - The section that explains the implementation of the APARD solution should be improved - Improve conclusions - The presentation: with spelling and writing errors, written in the first person, figures with very small letters, white letters in figures make it difficult to read, references written in a different way, etc. - It is recommended not to use Wikipedia as a reference for a scientific article - Missing author in references 6, missing topic name in reference 13 - Reference 7 is written with author differently from the others and with title before author - Change “Keywords” to

- According to the format, put at least 5 keywords - Put a reference in another format, for example, Greenfield and Short(2003) - There is a lot of detail on technologies and tools and products detailed in the APARD Technology Specification section - What does IQNET[z] mean? - I suggest putting the sections that make up the paper in the Introduction.

The topic of the article is new and necessary in the process modeling literature. The work in general presents a poor theoretical development. To carry out the comparison between the process modeling techniques, a methodology must be built that effectively shows the advantages of one method over the other. The comparison made between the methods must be presented for a general case, since nowhere does the methodology explain that it will be applied to a particular situation. The methodology of the article does not adequately explains the way in which the comparison was developed, it only exposes the decision criteria used in its construction, which does not allow an adequate evaluation of the results obtained. The research question and the objectives of the study carried out are not clearly stated.

review.remarks: Justification:
review.text: Justification: It is a job that is not very new, it is a subject that has been studied a lot, especially graphic models. These concepts are incorporated into the CASE tools, even though the document does not present them in depth Perhaps a greater contribution would have been to investigate the formal methods and broaden the comparative analysis of methods.

This paper is very interesting, I like the idea, and to make it a work publishable in vennue reaching a wider international audience it is necessary to validate the proposed ideas through extensive experimentation with actual data and users, please go ahead .

This paper proposes a new approach to support requirements prioritization through a process of transforming Use Cases into a dependency graph through the application of IR techniques, Bayesian networks and evaluation expert in the domain The approach is presented as an interesting contribution to the prioritization of requirements and shows its application to a real case The document is well written and very well supported by references The results are robust according to the approach used and are present well-directed future work Some typographical or editorial errors can be found on page 5 (paragraph 1 and 2) Confusion over the use of k and K on page 5 (or typo) Usage may not be clear knowledge of the prioritization performed in the test base case with respect to that performed semi-automatically by your approach, except that expert knowledge is used. between the two prioritizations would be appropriate.

From the point of view of Bayesian networks, the work does nothing more than a direct application of the Genie implementation of the K2 algorithm (Cooper and Hervokits, 1992). It is not clear what the algorithm is going to be used for. potential of this probabilistic graphical model at the level of inference or classification. The references included in the list must be refined (it makes no sense to include references from the 90s in which the "sent" tag appears.

review.remarks: Lack of clarity in the concepts and presentation of the proposal, which lacks references of contributions in the context of a very common problem.
review.text: The topic is current and the third mission is recreated through the proposal. I find it meritorious and interesting, in addition to the multiplier effect that this entails for companies and universities in addressing real problems, with "people " real. The article describes a case of business innovation that supports organizational learning processes. The main merit of the case is that a very significant impact has been achieved with a modest investment of resources. Additionally, knowledge is emphasized as an element strategic for the organization, which requires specific actions of management and allocation of resources. Finally, an impeccable and pleasant writing of the case should be highlighted.

The article describes an interesting application in the field of training that provides very useful tools for the company in improving the learning processes of workers. The article identifies the advantages that this type of platform provides to the companies that use them. The article does not adequately define its purpose and establishes at the beginning that this objective is "to make known", which is not an adequate purpose for these investigations. The article is called a platform for knowledge management, however the article does not define the appropriate theoretical framework for this topic (there are no relevant authors in knowledge management and the processes associated with it) The article does not adequately justify the relevance of these platforms in the literature in the learning process and international experiences on the subject There is no section that presents the research methodology selected by the authors, rather the authors describe an application and its components. The research design is clearly missing. The conclusions of the article are related to the importance of these platforms for the company, but they do not focus on the results obtained in the company that implements them, there are no recommendations for future studies and there is no recognition of its limitations

review.remarks: It is an interesting work, in a complex area, that is adequately presented. A greater effort could have been made to compare with other works in the same line that are currently being developed, under similar conditions.
review.text: Developing research associated with the subject of artificial vision is interesting to learn about, even under conditions that are not optimal, particularly in terms of hardware resources. In the lighting tests section there is a certain disorder in the presentation of the results (For example, figure 10. should be titled Chlorine Bottle Test and not Box Test). This makes it difficult to follow. The bibliographical references could be more current and of a better level.

The publication deals with a surface reconstruction system through scanning, using a conventional video camera, a motor and a laser. Under this scheme, a low-cost system is developed, with the advantages and limitations of the proposal - I believe that the proposed system is based on an interesting premise which is its low cost Commercial systems for this type of development can be, in most cases, very expensive, depending on the type of elements used. - Despite the simplicity of the proposed architecture, I think the system can be improved. For now, I think there is still a way to go (according to what I read in the paper) in terms of its use beyond the laboratory. That is why ORIGINALITY is rated 4 (good) - One of the first weaknesses found in the publication is its introduction. This sin, in my opinion, of two problems: The first pr The problem is that its content is too general, in its entirety it talks about what computer vision is, in general, but interesting aspects such as the state of the art in this matter and a relevant bibliography are not detailed. It only says in general terms: "In works related to this topic, it is generally the object that moves in millimeter form...". From this I have doubts such as: Are there other ways to reconstruct surfaces? Are there similar works? How is this technique different from others? What is the contribution of your work? Why not use stereo vision (perhaps the costs are similar)? The second problem found is a consequence of the first, since when trying to explain what computer vision is, it has been too long (a little more than three columns), and too general. Perhaps if attention had been focused on the state of the art, this would not be seen as a problem. - On the technical side, I see that your approach can work in a very controlled environment, where there are no big changes in lighting and the surface of the scanned objects have colors that are not very similar to the background and/or laser beam used. Background subtraction for controlled environments may work but outdoors I doubt your system will be as stable. I think the text could have listed the different methods used for segmentation. On page 4 it is referred to but not deepened ("Different methods were tried for segmentation, of which the image subtraction method was selected..."). Perhaps it would be good to take advantage of some color space (RBG, YUV, etc.) and use the Mahalanobis distance (get a sample of a laser beam or several) to get a better segmentation of the laser light. - About the presentation, I have found some errors that it would be good to improve: - Figure 2 and figure 3 have the same title, I think there is an error with the title of figure 3. - Figure 2 has some errors and that can lead to mistake "Light projector", the "of" is underlined. And "b" can be confusing since it appears with an underscore. - Some details: - Page 5: "The above generates them..." - Page 6: "which you get better..." - The laser word appears without a tilde on some occasions. Review the title that accompanies each page. - among others.
I AM NOT TRAINED TO CARRY OUT THIS REVISION. IT IS VERY FAR FROM MY SPECIALIZATION.

This paper presents important problems in its formulation. The papers of practical experiences must deliver something more than a simple description of the developed system: they must clearly indicate what new knowledge, technique or solution was obtained from said experience. Consequently, a A paper of this nature should include, at least, the following essential elements: - An introduction that clearly explains the purpose of the work: (a) the problem that was solved directly or indirectly with practical experience, (b) why the problem is important and non-trivial and (c) why this experience provided new information within that context (not obtained with similar experiences) - Theoretical framework - The description of the system: it should not be a mere enumeration of its components and functionalities, but clearly indicate those elements that, during their development, provided relevant information to the problem of the study - Conclusions: they must be r aligned with the elements of the introduction and must be supported by the evidence provided in the description of the system. Analyzing the paper from this perspective, we find important problems: First, the introduction is not clear regarding the purpose of the work and. The only part where the objectives are mentioned is in the 5th paragraph, where it is indicated that the case study is "to empirically demonstrate the development costs" associated with the technologies shown in the paper. This, along with "highlighting the main features and potential strengths of CakePHP and MVC.." seem to be the core elements of the paper. Second, the system description is not very different from a system manual; essential evidence is missing to support the elements of the introduction: associated development costs (time, people, resources) that are supposed to be lower than with another methodology. Although the sections describing CakePHP and MVC have information relevant to the problem, they do not add value to the work if they are not supported by evidence obtained directly from development experience with this technology. Above all, I missed a comparison with some other similar experience, clearly indicating what improvements CakePHP/MVC introduces to development. Finally, the conclusions of the paper are not aligned with the elements indicated in the introduction; some of them deliver information out of context (findings #5 and #6) or are irrelevant (finding #2); others lack supporting evidence (conclusion #1) or are not explicit in associating the evidence with the conclusion (conclusions #3 and #4). Apart from the previous observations, the paper also requires improvements in the presentation of the information. For example, the value that the SQL code in figures 10 and 11 deliver to the paper is not explicit. Figures 12-15 are not adequately described. A person who does not understand command line work well may end up totally disoriented and will not understand the arguments put forward. For all these reasons, the paper is not in a position to be accepted for publication.

Presents a framework for working with MVC with PHP in a simple way. Could be a little more technical in terms of configuration elements and add comparison with other existing frameworks to understand why CakePHP and not another alternative.

The paper exposes the application of the CakePHP framework to a specific problem. It clearly exposes the use of the MVC pattern through CakePHP. The introduction is very general and emphasizes elements (quality, time and RAD) that are not developed or demonstrated in depth in the work It presents the case study in CakePHP, without making a specific comparison based on the elements that are measurable (time, cost) with other frameworks It has misspellings (Universities) The use of of the extreme programming technique, however, it is not specified how it was developed by the authors SQL code is presented without specifying how it is related to the CakePHP framework The contribution of the screenshots presented is not clearly identified. A more detailed introduction to the specific problem solved would be desirable It is not clear what are the benefits of using CakePHP for the development of this application ation. The conclusions are very general and far from being specific to the work carried out.

The issue of citizen participation is today one of the issues at the government level that interests governments and citizens. The authors present an application that applies these concepts in the field of local government. The objective of the article is not The authors declare that the project associated with this article aims to develop methods that give social support to the participation of the citizens of Monteria in government processes and/or decisions.... On the other hand, they declare that the The objective is to provide an architecture to support group decision-making and communications, which facilitates citizen participation in those public processes related to decision-making, promote its use in important decisions and explore the political-legal aspects associated with it. However, these objectives refer to the project since they are not developed in the article.The authors must make the objective of the article clear. lo and this must be circumscribed to what is presented in it. The article also presents negative aspects fundamentally related to the review of the state of the art or the literature on the subject and the methodological development. In relation to the review of the literature, the authors do not present the main studies in the field of citizen participation in the world. There is an important number of publications that address this topic in the United States and Europe. E-government maturity models clearly address this area. Authors should exhaustively review the literature on the subject. The methodological aspect of the article is incomplete since it does not establish a research design that clearly identifies the tools to be used in each stage and their justification (comparatively), only two alternatives are mentioned but the reasons for their elimination are unknown. . Since the work is still in its implementation stage, it is difficult to determine the final benefits of the implementation, so the authors must highlight this limitation.

review.remarks: Very basic article in content.
review.text: It conforms to the requested format and can be read without difficulty. The article is basically a review of the XPath, Xquery and SQL/XML tools in Oracle 10g, illustrating their use with several examples. There is no contribution, in either new knowledge or application of technology to solve a real problem. There are no research results to show or discuss.

review.remarks: The article narrates an interesting experience from a practical point of view.
review.text: The article narrates the experience of the development of a robotic solution for the industrial problem of repairing electric motors. In particular, the problem of performing precision welding of electric motors by means of a robotic arm. The article presents practical aspects of the development of the solution, complemented with illustrations that help to understand the problem and the solution development process, understanding that it is an experience of technology transfer to the industry of specialized services that support the main regional economic activity (mining). , the following shortcomings were found: Aspects of form: 1. Non-technical terms are recurrently used, which confuse and do not provide objective background, in addition to writing and spelling errors, for example: children's errors --> it simply should be " failures" optimal results --> if "optimal" is used, evidence must be provided to support that it is the best best solution and there is no other better. quite high failure rate --> it is preferable to indicate that the estimated failure rate is 55% (5/9). "rather high" is ambiguous. solder --> solder? as required --> as required as General Electric, with very good results --> as General Electric, with good results. 2. always use third person. this was given to us --> this was given what we obtained is the following --> what was obtained was the following 3. It is not relevant to mention certain companies from which certain studies were purchased or commissioned: MOTORFIL, INDURA 4. It is assumed that the reader knows the terms and is able to identify parts such as coils and commutators from the figures. This should not be assumed, and should be explained clearly and simply, and its position illustrated in the figures where electric motors are shown. Names such as Innova Chile and their role in the project should be explained at the bottom of the page. 5. Figure 6 is relevant in the explanation. Unfortunately it is poorly readable and this needs to be fixed. 6. use global reachable terms rather than local. for example, cost close to a million pesos (Chilean?) --> cost equivalent to US$2,000 approx. 7. Graph 1 (must be Figure 4): standardize font sizes and indicate the variable on the X axis. Background aspects: 1. a background section is missing that allows later understanding of terms that are used later without having previously defined/explained them . In this sense, there is a paragraph that explains that it is a robot, but it appears in the Robotization of the Welding Process section, so it is misplaced. It must be before along with the other elements of the background. 2. When explaining how the robot was programmed, a drawing or figure is missing to support the explanation (reference plane, user plane, tool plane, etc.). The same is valid for the explanation of why an optical sensor was added (add an illustrative drawing or figure). 3. Statements are made that are not supported by references to studies or documents. On the contrary, the references are not cited within the body of the article. 4. Review the English version of the abstract. There are several writing and grammar errors. 5. There is no detailed technical information on how the robot programming steps were carried out, for example. There are only general descriptions.
