review.text: Abstract: Needs to have a definition of ERP - can't assume the reader knows what this means. Intro: Avoid 1 sentence paragraphs (page 1) The introduction is rather long - it seems to actually be two different sections : an introduction (1st four paragraphs) and 1+ page of background and hypothesis.Overall - at 1.5 pages the intro is rather long for a paper that is 4 pages total.Methodology: I think there are a lot of assumptions in regards to what ERP are and how they work.While the paper is a statistical study, it would have benefited with a context of an actual example.The samples are from small to medium size companies (how many?) with 49 use case (how do these relate Results: Discussion is too limited - it assumes that a reader is very familiar with the area, and that may not be the case.

review.remarks: The topic has already been dealt with in other perhaps much more complete studies that also consider the attributes of the problem domain.
review.text: The article presents a study of the perception that requirements engineers (novices and experts) have in relation to the effectiveness of the different elicitation techniques for the discovery of requirements in a software development project. This article deals with a topic that deserves some attention given the large number of elicitation techniques that exist and the disorientation of requirements engineers regarding which one to use in a certain context.The study carried out considers as novice Engineers who do not have knowledge of elicitation techniques and one of the attributes that must be qualified as the basis of the comparative study is precisely their experience.In fact, as a conclusion, it is stated that
, that is a platitude. A wider range of context attributes should be considered, such as those suggested in [14], which allow more truthful conclusions.

It is a study carried out under a formal methodology (grid technique). The objective behind the study is to improve the preparation of strategies for training in requirements elicitation techniques, which is a contribution given the relevance of the Requirements Engineering in software development.The study covers a wide variety of education techniques, among which the most used in practice are incorporated.The study was applied to people who belong to a single institution (Polytechnic University of Madrid) , without a doubt this is a limitation since they all have exactly the same training, it would be interesting to apply the study to new engineers with different training. The conclusions obtained from the study are not new, they confirm what could be expected logically.

The article presented briefly describes the studies carried out and the decisions adopted, which allow the ESO Paranal and Cerro Armazones observatories, located in the Atacama desert, to be provided with a high-capacity infrastructure. The various stages involved in the challenge of providing a large bandwidth to the aforementioned observatories located in unpopulated areas (full desert) for their expeditious connection with various academic networks and the European astronomical community, which constitutes a good challenge from the technological point of view. It is important to highlight the reason for the need to have large bandwidths, that is, to describe in greater detail the type of traffic that justifies it, for example monitoring, control and remote operation, etc. The link is not yet in operation

It presents a work of great relevance for science in Chile, mentioning elements that are very necessary for the development of high-performance communications in the technological and research poles. It could go deeper into a brief technical description of the technology that is mentioned in the paper, since the job is not self-contained.
It is a large-scale project that needs to be known by the academic community. It will include the values of the project in the presentation

The article performs a performance comparison for GPU and CPU-based implementations for the same algorithm. GPU programming is a very hot topic in HPC. There are problems in the presentation of the article and the images do not are well contextualized. Implementations and performance comparisons between GPU and CPU are a topic already addressed in existing works. The article describes in a relatively specific way the implementation and its details, together with the problems encountered. The topic of GPU programming is a topic very current in high-performance computing and its comparison with CPU-based programming seems relevant to me. It would be advisable to improve the order of the article, better relating the images and tables. There are evident misspellings within the content of the work.

The manuscript involves the use of GPUs, a technology that for a couple of years has had more and more to say in the area of HPC. The document has a relatively good structure, comparisons are made and there are some interesting graphics. The document has some shortcomings that make it confusing, for example, page 7 is a complete mess, Figure 7 is not well explained, the tables are treated as figures, there is a difference between what an image and a graph represent, for which they should be treated independently. There is a text that explains Figure 6, which by the way is a table, that text is not part of the body of the paper, is it? It is very difficult to read that page. I am not an expert in the SIFT algorithm, so when reading the paper it is not clear to me if they used the SiftGPU code created by Changchang Wu or took it as a base and applied some modifications to it. On the other hand, it would have been interesting to know why the implementation in CUDA, the implementation in multicore and the serial could give different results, if after all the three approaches are the SIFT algorithm. I have been programming parallel applications for more than 12 years and for the same algorithm I have never observed different results, if after all the algorithm is the same, now, when variants are introduced to the original algorithm in order to force parallelism, have different results, but it is no longer the original algorithm. Reading other papers on the subject, I do not find so much originality, the document does not help much to draw conclusions either. The paper has data from runs and compares different approaches, but I still have a big question as to why the same algorithm with a sequential approach and a parallel one with GPU can yield different results. GPU is an issue that has its thanks, especially for the money savings that its use implies in the long term, so it could be good to spread this work to spread this technology. The document is messy, it is necessary to differentiate what is a figure, a graph and a table, besides page 7 is very difficult to read and the explanation of the data tables is confused with the body of the paper.

The article generally proposes an architecture based on the Windows Azure platform to develop applications for Cloud Computing, which is a very current paradigm in computing technologies. Some indicators or comparisons of why to use Windows would be appreciated Azure and not other platforms for applications in Cloud Computing The use of Windows Azure for the development of an application for Cloud Computing does not seem very original to me and the proposed architecture is based on MVC, which is widely used in the area of development of applications. The article describes in a very general way the concepts of Cloud Computing, MVC, Web Services and REST. The topic of Cloud Computing is a current paradigm of computing, and from that point of view, the article is relevant. It would be appreciated to define the acronyms at least once, define whether to speak of "the cloud" or "the cloud", references in the "Proposed Architecture" section and some figures s that they will show the proposed architecture.

- Description of the components of the Windows Azure cloud computing platform. - Brief description of the cloud computing concept. - There is no discussion regarding the possible disadvantages or adverse scenarios of a "cloud implementation" - The summary talks about "... detailing the experience in building a platform to build public and open clouds", but it is only limited to the description of the Azure platform - Very little depth in the description of the application that is mounted on the cloud platform. Given the title and abstract, more analysis is expected in terms of the advantages and disadvantages of development using this platform. - Writing problems within the work itself. - Certain sections seem more like a "brochure" commercial than an academic paper.

The paper has a relatively coherent structure, it introduces a series of concepts that could be useful for someone who does not know the subject, it talks about architectural patterns and describes windows azure For someone who knows the subject it is tedious to read already known definitions, on the other hand, the title of the paper is not consistent with what is written in the manuscript, in fact at times it gave me the feeling of reading a commercial brochure more than a scientific work, cloud computing and especially its implementations, such as windows Azure have advantages and disadvantages, to mention some disadvantages: loss of control, performance, privacy, in Latin America all countries have serious bandwidth problems, for which cloud computing can be more of a risk than a benefit if not improved a basic aspect, to improve data networks. I think the case study should have been explained more, since it is the essence that shows whether cloud computing and Is it useful or is it just another buzzword that the commercial area of IT companies wants to sell us. The paper is mainly limited to explaining concepts and benefits rather than showing the benefits and qualities through an example or practical case. The case study is not detailed and the development of applications is not seen from a critical point of view, only positive aspects are mentioned and not the negative ones. Although cloud is a current term, after participating in several conferences on grid computing and collaborative systems, I am still not sure if cloud is a buzzword in the commercial area or if it really has something new that the concepts that were coined before did not have, although I do not know a critical and objective view of the subject, in parts it looks like a commercial brochure, I believe that an open discussion of the subject can be generated to help answer the doubts that exist around the term cloud computing. The paper has writing errors in the abstract, however, it has coherence and an evolution of the topic, although the topic in which it evolves is not aligned with the title of the document.

The paper introduces a segmentation procedure for breast tissue images using SVM. General comments: a) Concerning the proposed approach: The segmentation method introduced only considers local color/gray value information. Perhaps introducing other features related to the membrane's local (eg the membrane has symmetry properties that can be exploited) or global (eg continuity, approximately circular shape) properties may improve the segmentation results.Feature selection is also a key component to improve performance.Use a feature selection procedure. b) Concerning the experimentation: You should describe the experiments with sufficient detail so others can replicate them: a) Make your data publicly available b) Explain how you have selected the classifier's parameters (parameter selection in an SVM is critical and may improve notably the performance). You should join Figs 10 and 9 in a single plot so we can better see the differences. You only provide qualitative segmentation results (Figs. 12, 14, 15), but quantitative results are also very important. Especially when it comes to comparisons. You should quantitatively compare your algorithm with other competing works in the literature. c) Concerning paper organization: The paper is well written and clearly introduces the problem, describes the relevant literature and presents the solution. I have a few comments concerning the paper organization: a) Problem statement and literature review (intro and theoretical framework sections) are in my opinion a bit long, compared to other important sections, e.g. feature extraction and experimentation which are just one paragraph each. b) Although English is in general correct, there are some small mistakes that could be solved by having it read by a professional. c) There are two "proposed method" sections Well written paper. Good literature review. It only shows very preliminary results.

This work demonstrates a breast tissue image segmentation approach for binary image pixel classification using SVM to determine the presence or absence of cancer cell membrane staining This work is interesting and valuable, due to the difficulty of obtaining this type of images and the interdisciplinary approach, also presenting an interesting future work.It is well written and the results shown, although partial, seem correct and justified.Check wording and typography on page 4 in its first and penultimate paragraphs. The main weakness of this work may be the low number of test images and the lack of comparison with other methods. It would also be desirable to show general results of the classification and not only of the validation process. In addition, the properties explained in the scoring table (completeness and intensity) are not used directly in the sorting process.

The paper presents a medical test based on images of tissue sections. The proposed approach to cancer cells segmentation (membrane localisation) is based on local pixel features and SVM classification. The paper describes quite well the practical problem it deals with (cancer cells segmentation on images) and it is generally well written.- The paper approach described in the paper seems a first try on the problem and follows others in a quite similar (but new) problem. approach is not good enough.- The features used for classification lacks of frequency information around each pixel (although it used the first derivative with sobel).Most texture descriptors in the literature use frequency information from gabor wavelets, fourier coefficients, DCT, etc. Why not use this kind of information? Why you have chosen this 7 features and not other ones? The paper lacks of experimental evaluation on different features sets.
The article presented describes how to model a multi-agent system according to the

agent-oriented methodology to model requirements traceability. The GAIA proposal to model requirements traceability using multi-agent systems seems to be novel The presentation of the article is quite confusing, the document has some spelling, writing and structuring errors, it refers to tables that are figures, unreferenced tables are presented, figure 6 does not exist, the item
must be changed or described elsewhere in the document. Insufficient conclusions.

- The article describes various approaches to developing requirements, and applies one of them (GAIA) to the construction of multi-agent systems (MAS). - The Introduction is very long and covers many topics; it should be divided into several sections, and leave in Introduction only the general context and description of the rest of the article - There is no example to illustrate the technique, which is described in 1.5 pages, being the essence of the contribution - There is no validation of any kind .

The use of the GAIA methodology is proposed for traceability to requirements, the proposed approach is based on the social capacity of agents to process knowledge, perceive changes in the environment and communicate. It is a complex task , since a great variety of models and diagrams are used in software development that facilitate the representation of knowledge, these artifacts are modified over time. These changes come mainly from the user. It is required to deepen the practical application of the proposal to better evaluate the scientific and practical contribution.

review.remarks: I think this is an attractive topic, which should be encouraged in order to promote technological solutions that solve real problems. There are weaknesses in the presentation of the article that are correctable.
review.text: The development of a web framework for the management of IP cameras is interesting. A topic that is, for me, new and that can be extended in its usefulness. There are writing and presentation problems (for example, " It has an IP camera which can ..."). In addition, it is unclear if applications have been developed on the framework and if they work properly.

review.remarks: It is required to show more results on the effective consumption of bandwidth on the trunk to the server. It is necessary to improve the writing.
review.text: Shows a mix of web technologies for your development and implements a native solution. It doesn't show how much bandwidth is consumed on the trunks by the application when the cameras are all working together. Needs to show more results.

The work presents the development of a web framework for transmission with the ability to analyze images from IP cameras. The bibliography presented are web pages related to the tools used for development, but not related topics or other related applications .Formatting issues (check spelling, line breaks when it shouldn't, indentation, It indicates in the summary that the system has parsing capability, but in the end it indicates that it is disabled. What is the advantage of saving in real Ips usage? An analysis of the previous situation with the current one is missing. How did the system improve.

- The article deals with a relevant and fashionable problem in the community (eg CMMI-ACQ). - There is no state of the art that reviews previous attempts to solve this problem. - The definition of patterns of acquisition project should adhere to the usual definitions of pattern (especially when compared to design patterns, as is done in the Conclusions), i.e. the Portland style of design patterns recognizes context, problem and solution. technique used (MECT) seems adequate for building taxonomies, but not patterns (by excluding causality considerations etc.); the article seems to assume that "design patterns" are "form patterns", and they are not - Reference [13] wrongly lists the author's name.

This is a topic that has not been addressed sufficiently and for that reason it is good to treat it "serious". Precisely because of what was stated above, it is that this topic can "get more out of match". Although I consider the deduced classification adequate, I think it could have been a little more in-depth.

The article presents an eye detection and monitoring system to help psychological clinical analysis. General comments. A lot has been published on the subject addressed by the article. However, no other directly related relevant works are cited, which help us locate the proposal within the literature A good starting point may be the special issue of the journal: Computer Vision and Image Understanding Volume 98 , Issue 1 (April 2005) Special issue on eye detection and tracking The experimental part of the The work is very brief. It is important to describe in detail the data used in the experimentation, what the capture conditions are, and even make them public so that other researchers can compare them. As for the results, it is not enough to give a percentage of successes False positives and negatives must be analyzed and related to the technique used and, if possible, to future research topics. Other comments: The article mentions that response speed has been considered, but no figures are provided. In the introduction reference [3] is cited in the related review on the psychological aspects of the article, when this reference seems to be of mathematical morphology. Some references are incomplete: + In 1 and 2 the editorial is missing + In 3 the conference/magazine. + In page 5 the volume, number and pages The article deals with a subject of great technical and practical interest. A system is described that appears not to be fully developed.

The work presents an eye position detection system under development to support the psychological analysis of a person. A way to detect eyeballs and their direction is presented. In addition to a small mention of C/C++ no the use of support libraries is explicitly specified, such as filters, image capture, etc. It is mentioned that the response speed of the system has been considered, however, no evidence of this factor is presented. data set on which the study was carried out, if it is pre-existing or was developed specifically for this work by the authors Details of the faces of this data set are not presented (age, race, sex, etc.) It is not specified whether the results obtained were reviewed by a professional in the clinical area and their conclusions. The references are very few in relation to the field of work developed.

This work proposes a part of an unfinished system to recognize and interpret eye movement as a support tool for a psychologist. It is an interesting topic. Although it is an interesting topic, the problem to be solved is not well explained and no eye movement interpretation results shown Could have used more sheets to explain this Missed part of analysis of results Formatting issues (wording issues, spelling, there are equations where you don't explain terms, you should write in the third person) The presentation modality was in 4 or 10 pages, however it only presents 3 pages.

This paper shows the results of developing a CBIR based on metric distance indices, comparing it with existing systems through retrieval accuracy and comparing time efficiency results for different indexing approaches such as GNAT, NAT, etc. The work addresses an important problem of recovery systems, its structure is correct and the results appear to be substantiated Perhaps the evaluation criteria are not sufficient to determine the superiority of one approach over another, although the authors acknowledge the main shortcomings regarding this point and visualize future work in this direction.The explanation of section 2.3, on precision, is unclear in defining how it is known in advance about the correct images most similar to a query in order to calculate the The time graphs in figure 3 do not indicate the scale.

This work shows the results We have developed a CBIR based on metric distance indices, comparing it with existing systems through retrieval accuracy and comparing time efficiency results for different indexing approaches such as GNAT, NAT, etc. The work addresses an important problem of recovery systems, its structure is correct and the results appear to be well founded. Perhaps the evaluation criteria are not enough to be able to determine the superiority of one approach over another, although the authors recognize the main shortcomings regarding this point and envision future work in this direction. The explanation of section 2.3, on precision, is unclear in defining how it is known in advance about the correct images most similar to a query in order to calculate precision. The time graphs in figure 3 do not indicate the scale.

The article deals with the construction of image retrieval systems based on the content (of the images), CBIR. The CBIR problem is introduced and some algorithms are presented that allow to speed up searches for nearest neighbors to a input vector (corresponding to an image) in the feature space chosen to represent the images Color, frequency response, and global features are used for each of the local frames into which an input image is divided In this way, information of different types is introduced into the CBIR system to represent the images - The article does not clearly delimit its contributions It seems that something is contributed in terms of the space of characteristics in which the images are represented and it also seems that it contributes something on the algorithms and data structures needed to speed up searches in metric spaces - In general the article uses little space in explaining the proposed approach to CBIR (two references to master's theses are given). Experimental results are presented in the conclusions, when clearly they should go in a previous section with the experiments. - Regarding the visual characteristics used to represent an image: Experiments are lacking that allow establishing what each of the characteristics proposed to use contributes. That is, I think it is important to answer the question: Why are you here and not others? and also to the question: Is any of them redundant and could it be stopped being used? Although it is true that a feature selection procedure is used, an experiment establishing the effect of the selection is missing. How much is gained in success rate over the use of the complete vector? It appears that the feature space after selection has dimension 3078 (section 2.4). Is that right or have the 3078 features been

extracted? - The CBIR systems comparison experiment (section 2.3) is not understood. What is done with the 100 images common to databases? Is the same query made in all systems and is precision and recall measured using only the 100 common images when they appear or not in the system's response? That is not explained at all in the article. - When data such as sensitivity and specificity are given in the conclusions, it must be said on which data set it has been tested. It is possible to do a test on some data and obtain a completely different result on others. Therefore sensitivity and specificity without reference to the data from which it has been obtained are meaningless. - It seems to this reviewer that an article on CBIR should not overlook developments in Computer Vision based on (already classic) local features such as: Sivic, J. and Zisserman, A. Video Google: A Text Retrieval Approach to Object Matching in Videos Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision (2003) D. Nistér and H. Stewénius, Scalable recognition with a vocabulary tree Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (2006) - Some of the references, such as the [10,11,13], are incomplete. What do they mean? An article? An example system running on a URL? - The system working on the URL that the authors refer to gives execution errors when trying to test with images extracted from google images.

The publication aims to show the benefits of metric structures for image retrieval. This work is the continuation of several works already presented, such as [1] "Parallel metric structures in image retrieval of images", Peña-Jaramillo, E. (Referenced in the paper) [2] "Definition of an Image retriever based on Contents on Metric Spaces", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et al. (Not referenced). [3] "Parallel Metric Structures in the Retrieval of Images on the Web", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et al. (Not referenced) About reference number [1] it has not been possible to obtain an electronic copy, and since the aforementioned publications [2] and [3], it can be said that there is a new contribution in the experiments carried out on GNAT and Spaghetti structures, it should be explained in the publication that the work is not original from the author's point of view, and that its extension is based on the works [1], [2], [3] or another that is directly related to the work presented. - The text is well structured and it is easy to understand what you want to expose. - Good presentation, no serious problems. Only improve the figures of the graphs, especially the accents, in matlab you can add text in latex to avoid this type of problem. The word "more" appears a couple of times without a tilde. - In the "Introduction" section, although the work is presented in a general way, I think it would be important to point out the state of the art in these matters. Are there related works? Are there important references? What is the contribution of the work to the state of the art?, etc. A more exhaustive bibliographic review is lacking. - In the "Feature Extraction" section I have found some details such as: - It has been difficult for me to find a definition of the layout technique since there is only one reference [1], so I suspect that features have been considered obtained from each sub-image as a signal which are mixed to obtain the vector that represents the total image, as it says in the text: "The union of all the extracted characteristics gives us as a result...", where it is not clear what type of "join" is performed. - The same thing also happens when the Fisher discriminant is referenced, again reference is made to [1]. A more relevant source should be added for this point. - The type of database used is not explained in detail. Is it public or private domain? What kind of images or groups of images it contains. How many are there per class? Are there repeated images? Quality of the images. The idea is to have a frame of reference so that anyone who wants to compare their algorithms with theirs can do so on equal terms. - From the images shown in figure 2, I can deduce that the database (I hope I am wrong) has repeated images, which can produce a bias when calculating the values of precision, sensitivity and specificity of the retrieved images. I believe that the ideal database to be able to correctly measure the quality of the recovery should have different images even if they have the same appearance, but never the same. Since when retrieving a set of images over a query image, if they are repeated, the number of true positives will be proportional to the repeated ones, which will result in a bias on the calculation of the metrics. Recommendations - In the text it is mentioned (conclusions section) that the solutions are not entirely satisfactory. I think there are currently projects like http://similar-images.googlelabs.com/, http://www.like.com/, http://www.tineye.com/, among others; that show great progress in this field and would be good to be reviewed. - On the other hand, regarding the set of features used, I recommend reviewing other types of features that have been shown to be invariant to scale and rotation. [4] "Distinctive Image Features from Scale-Invariant Keypoints". David G. Lowe. International Journal of Computer Vision, 2004. as well as its improvement [5] "SURF: Speeded Up Robust Features", Computer Vision and Image Understanding (CVIU). Herbert Bay, Andreas Ess , Tinne Tuytelaars, Luc Van Gool. Vol. 110, No. 3, pp. 346--359, 2008.

review.remarks: The article needs improvement mainly in reinforcing two things:
review.text: General comments: • It is recommended to review all the writing since there are extra words or words written in the wrong way, for example: incomplete, items (page 3); quedede (page 4), del de (page 5) … etc • Check the spacing of the words • Check the numbering of the bibliography since it has to be listed in the order it appears in. • Check that the text is the same size (example: end first column page 1) Comments by Sections II SCRUM AND SPEM • Reference the part dedicated to SCRUM as well as the figure since it is not the authors' own but taken from someone else III ASSESSMENT OF REQUIREMENTS USING SPEM • Review the concept of stakeholder or reference which reference used that concept, For example, I include the concepts of stakeholder for CMMI: “Stakeholder A group or individual who is affected by or is in some way responsible for the result of a company” “Stakeholder A group or individual who is affected by or is in some way responsible for the result of a company” IV SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT WITH SCRUM • Title of Figure 5, the title of the figure can be improved for example: software development process model based on SCRUM and using SPEM for its modeling • It is recommended to reinforce the section by adding references to the terms V METRICS TO DEFINE THE QUALITY OF SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT • It is recommended to add references when describing the concepts of metrics VI A CASE STUDY • It is recommended to improve the description of Table I (content of columns and operation or operations carried out to establish the weight and evaluation standard deviations) • There is a vignette without text below Table 1 • It is recommended to support the section with a graph or table showing a summary of the quality measurement, to understand the
measurement that is mentioned in the conclusions

The article promises to present a method to measure the quality of software development in SCRUM. I consider the proposal interesting and relevant, however the work has weaknesses in its construction. The promise of the title is diluted in the abstract and the introduction, with the

of SPEM as a tool. Then, in the body of the article, the link between SPEM and the proposed quality measurement method is not clear. The case study on which they are basing their work is not clear either. modeling in SPEM is about SCRUM theoretically in the case study. The evaluation of the method does not seem to measure the quality of the software, but rather the criteria of those involved with respect to adherence to the modeled process. And in any case, it always measures documents intermediate of the process and no defects or first attributes of the quality of the software produced Minor comments: - Review the construction of the references - The SCRUM modeling does not include the retrospective meeting. If you are modeling a particular SCRUM implementation, make it clear in the body of the paper. Otherwise it is a major modeling error. - Why do you use a traditional process to model an agile process? Couldn't one of the latter have been used? - On the first sheet, at the end of the first column, change the font.

Interesting work that deals with the simulation of urban environments to simulate accidents and measure the effects of urban interventions that help in their prevention. The work is a contribution both from the point of view of its objective, and of the detailed description of the technology integration process that allowed it to be carried out, which can be replicated for projects that use 3d technology for other purposes, as well as the strategies used to refine the model through hot air balloons. It is missing, yes, a review of similar works to have established a comparison.

This is an interesting work, where the author wants to show Honeynets as an alternative security measure, to learn how intruders operate and thus create new forms of protection. Observations: - The name of the only author must be centralized in the article. - Words and figures in English. The article is in Spanish. - References are inadequate: there is only one article cited and with incomplete reference. Improve the bibliographic review, citing current articles and books.

ABSTRACT. The paper describes the steps to follow to apply fuzzy logic concepts to mobile devices. To exemplify the steps, the author used a mobile robot called AMADEUS (similar to cleaning robots marketed in Japan [1 ]). To apply the concepts of fuzzy logic, the Mamdani module was used. General Evaluation. The topic is extremely interesting and very recurrent lately. Devices that use fuzzy logic to operate is a very interesting and innovative bridge between Artificial Intelligence and "pervasive computing ". However, this work has at least one important weakness that should be resolved: 1) In the work it does not show why it is really important to use fuzzy logic. An application example is strongly recommended for the work. How would using fuzzy logic help? 2) At work it is not very clear to me if the use of fuzzy logic in mobile devices is something new in this area, if it is not something new, perhaps the work could become only a repetition of another work. If it's something new, please mention it. Minor Comments: - In the conclusions, the phrase "it was demonstrated" is mentioned; it is suggested to change to "showed". - Pay attention to the use of punctuations (eg "...", ".") and the use of capital letters. - At the end of the introduction, it is suggested to mention the structure of the document. [1] Auto Mee: www.yumeki.org/comercilizaran-little-robot-cleaner-of-dispositives-tactiles

review.remarks: This article could be presented in the robotics workshop.
review.text: This article is not a research article, as it only shows how to program a robot using the fuzzy logic tool. This topic has already been proposed as a solution in robot navigation.

review.remarks: Thank you for your reviews,
review.text: The work, according to the reviewers, does not present a direct scientific contribution in the area of robotics or fuzzy systems, however it is a very interesting application to be presented at the INFONOR 2013 Robotics Workshop. That is why it is recommended to accept the article for submission.

This article proposes a system that adds fuzzy components to certain attributes of a database with information on the physical state of people. The application of the work is interesting, since there are few experiences where they are used in practice fuzzy attributes for storage and consultation in our country, so it can make the subject matter interesting for our congress.However, the following aspects are either unclear or incomplete: - Use the format requested by the congress - Improve writing overview of the summary/introduction - Write point 3, 4.1.1 in the third person when referring to the client - Take care with the use of abbreviations that are sometimes used in lower or upper case - Write the conclusion with an approach that makes it clear what benefits obtained by the user of the system with respect to a non-fuzzy system - It is not clear how the membership functions used were determined - Missing some ti Type of study/comparison to check the contribution that a system like the one proposed improves or complements a traditional system in the applied area Due to the above, it is recommended to accept the article for presentation in the Business Applications Workshop.

A Learning Object serves as support for the educational process, to develop skills in students in one of the three types of knowledge (conceptual mastery, procedural mastery and development of attitudes and values). In none of these areas evidence is given to prove it. In addition to the fact that the experiences are very basic, the abstract, I quote it verbatim: "The Article presents, the experiences gathered from the application of Learning Objects in the development of the subject of Introduction to the Theory of Automata, due to the fact that significant changes have been deployed in the development of the course, proposing a detailed and exhaustive academic follow-up through a
and
scheme.", the experiences collected are not shown nor are mention how they would get them.

The need to use Learning Objects (LO) for the teaching of the course "Introduction to the Theory of Automata" is presented. However, very little information is dedicated in the article to the LOs chosen for the course, there is no information on the results of its application or its consequences (learning results, student survey to validate it, etc.) That is why it is not recommended to accept the article, unless information is added that supports the application of OA in this course.

review.remarks: The topic is interesting, we are not talking about a methodological contribution, it is an interesting application.
review.text: The article is interesting because of the subject it addresses and the results of the analyzes carried out, rather than the methodology itself. I still have doubts about how the analyzes are fed with new information and how the system is integrated to USACH's transactional systems. However, it is an interesting application.

review.remarks: The idea is good but it must fix what is requested in the list of corrections both in terms of format and content. And especially the title, which is very "big" in relation to what is presented, which is an application and not a new emerging model.
review.text: 1.	What is proposed is interesting as an application but it is not a scientific work. 2.	In the summary nothing is indicated regarding the proposed methodology, which is why perhaps the title
.... It should be oriented to
. 3.	No methodology is proposed, it is an

application but not a methodology. 4.	On page 3 correct wording error “in Figure 1, organized as.” 5.	The idea of what is being proposed needs to be better substantiated, that is, to carry out a “clear” analysis of the advantages of why the proposal is interesting and important. For example, a table can be made with the advantages over other models, just as this does not indicate an advantage over other methods because other methods are not analyzed.

The article proposes, according to the article, a computational platform related to academic information from the USACH Propedeutic. Later, in "III. Development of the Proposal" a methodology is proposed. It is not clear if it is a computational platform, if it is a methodology, if it is a systematization of information... The Abstract must be improved, as well as the Conclusions. The article is brief, could have presented the proposal better if it had been a little longer (the proposal is presented in less than 2 pages) Other observations: - Change "Reserved Words" to "Keywords" - In Introduction, the web pages mentioned must be declared in References. - References are confused with the identification of sub-section titles. For example: "[1] Multicriteria Decision" (not Reference 1). - On page 3, change \
for "organized". - On page 5, it says "Table 2", it should say "Table 3".

review.remarks: Dear Reviewers,
review.text: This paper, according to the reviewers, does not directly contemplate a scientific contribution, however the experience and the topic discussed are interesting to present at the congress. Although it cannot be presented as a regular paper at the congress, It is recommended to accept the article for presentation at the Infonor 2013 education workshop.

ABSTRACT: The paper reports the steps followed to use SAP ERP software at Embonor, a producer and distributor of Coca-Cola products. Before reporting this experience, this company already had some SAP modules implemented (Financial, FI-CO, Logistics, Human Resources) General Evaluation Although the work does not present a scientific structure of an article, it is extremely interesting (in my opinion) to hear in more detail about this experience in infonor 2013. The document tries to show an evaluation of software quality attributes based on the ISO 9126 standard. The document shows a proposal for a template with a series of questions to analyze the quality of different quality attributes of a software product developed. However, the document lacks structure. The writing is deficient. In some parts of the document, the formatting parameters required in the author guide are not followed. For example, the abstract is centered and according to the guide of the event must be justified Some paragraphs of the document are presented in the same way As for the writing, the document is difficult to read, punctuation marks are missing or misplaced Keywords do not match as keywords in the article. There is a lack of bibliographical references to support the statements that are made.Although the template can be as useful as they try to ensure in the work, it is necessary to bu seek a more consolidated validation that allows to ensure its usefulness. The statistics presented lack valid justifications and the presentation format is poor. Much of the document focuses on making claims described in the ISO 1926 standard and: 1. It is not properly cited as the main reference of the work. 2. Focusing the article to summarize the definition of each characteristic or sub-characteristic of the standard does not seem very appropriate for this type of work. The presentation format of the template lacks clarity. It seems that it is a questionnaire format but it is not shown as such. There is a list of unclear statements and questions. Some of these questions are mentioned in the results, however they do not appear in the list named by the author as "template", it is the case of: Does the system operate together with another system? In general terms, the work must refine much more.

The article presents a case study of the application of a template to measure quality according to the ISO 9126 standard. Although it is true that it fits within the scope of the event and its proposal may be of interest to software engineers who wish to have some practical instrument to apply in their quality systems, the work has serious deficiencies that must be improved to be published. The technical presentation of the document has shortcomings that do not meet the standards established for writing the article. In particular, we can mention some : - Formatting is not uniform as can be seen in the abstract which has different length settings. There are also differences in spacing after each paragraph. Sometimes it exists and sometimes it doesn't. Bullets have different indentations. Bibliographical references have different indentations. - The most serious is the spelling and writing. The document requires a thorough editing revision. In only the first two paragraphs of the introduction I have found more than 5 faults. Regarding its structure, I think it should be reorganized to improve its presentation. I think the objectives should go inside the introduction. The presentation of the ISO criteria should be summarized in a descriptive table. It's annoyingly long and I think it can be referenced for details. On the other hand, I think it should be clarified if the template is pre-existing or is a proposal of the work, in which case it should be highlighted since it would be the main contribution of the article. Your presentation is unfortunate. I think it should be summarized in a table and clearly state what can be answered. Most are not even presented as questions. I insist that if the template is the contribution it should be made easier for other engineers to use. Your presentation does not help this. (eg the first, "When interacting with the system, please note how predictable it is": what do I say?) The instrument should be self-contained so that it clearly contains guidance for its application. Furthermore, it doesn't provide clarity on how I combine query responses to get a quality metric. I think there is too much work left for the reader. The results are not presented in a readable way. I think a table would help. It even mentions several times the tabulation of the results but this does not appear. As it is a case study, I would like to see in that table the answers that were obtained and how the percentages that measure quality were calculated.

It should use Business Intelligence, instead of Business Intelligence. These models are surely defined for large companies in the United States, therefore they work equally well in Chilean companies? Maturity in Business Intelligence in companies from developed countries is different from countries like Chile It is not necessary to include point II by itself In point V, paragraph 2, it indicates that an adaptation of DEA is described and does not specify the reference or if it is an adaptation proposed by authors, as well as indicating why an adaptation is used On page 4, first paragraph indicates that the Hierarchy model is excluded and then returns to it. incorporate in the following steps. The article presents a quantitative comparison (DEA Technique) and a qualitative comparison (MESME Methodology) of selected BI maturity models. review.remarks: Thank you for your evaluations, apparently the article is not written correctly but it can be used in a discussion for the congress.
review.text: ABSTRACT. The article seeks to show the applications of Biological Immune Systems in computing. To do this, the article begins by describing the theory of the Biological Immune System of vertebrates, which defines, in addition to explaining its operation. then describes the biological models as a theoretical review of the subject. Finally describes the characteristics of artificial immune systems and details the different fields of application. General Evaluation. The subject of the article is extremely interesting, and rarely seen (at least by me) As the article posits, it makes a bibliographic review of the theory and provides a description of the variety of applications that this field of study has. It manages to summarize these concepts that can effectively serve as a frame of reference within literature. However, the article has some weaknesses: 1) The great weakness of the article is its structure The article does not follow the format or standard of work of a scientific article. Here I present some examples. a) The introduction does not present the structure that the article follows, nor a general idea of what the authors want to achieve. b) There is no outline of the ideas of each section, nor an introduction per section. This means that there is no clear proposal by the authors and what they try to propose is only seen on the last page. 2) Another weakness is that it does not establish any way to evaluate and compare the different applications of the subject in order to connect them with the theory and present a contribution of the article. For this reason, it does not comply with what is established in its abstract: " . . . to establish guidelines in the application of these techniques in the different areas of knowledge." 3) Another problem is that it does not establish any type of conclusion or of the implications of the article, which ends with the description of an application in combinatorial optimization. Other comments. Minor drafting problems: a) "...and molecules belonging to external (not self) antigens, which ultimately constitute a threat to the organism..." It is understood that a word is missing after “ last”. b) "describe basic features of an immune response" This phrase does not establish a definition. c) "innate immune cells specialized dendritic cells" Words are missing here too.

- Ambitious in the title, achievements exposed in the article rather moderate. - TOGAF reference is questionable in the tenor of the article. - How were the reference models selected??? What other models exist and were not considered??

This article presents the development of a Syn-Flood and Satan attacks detection system through clustering techniques based on the DBSCAN algorithm in 5-minute time windows. There may be new knowledge, but the document does not reflect as the system carried out helped to obtain new knowledge of the attacks. - There is little explanation and lack of experimentation to argue and justify the use of DBSCAN on another type of clustering or even instead of a classifier. - It is known that an attack SYN-FLOOD produces a high number of connections at a given time, so it is not clear if it is necessary such a sophisticated system to detect this phenomenon, this could be clarified if comparison was included with other approaches .

RESUME. This work describes three of teaching activities in an elective course at the University of La Serena. Develop interpreters using the Antlr tool on Android is the main connection of these activities. The first activity implements a parser / interpreting for a calculator. The second activity incorporates the ability to order lists in the interpreter. The last activity incorporates the voice recognition service using a Google bookstore. According to work, the result of these activities allowed students to better understand the concepts of formal languages. GENERAL EVALUATION: The work describes very clearly how activities were carried out in the elective course. However, from my point of view, the work presents two great weaknesses: 1) The main motivation of work is that the use of Antlr tools are useful for formal languages courses. However, a sample of why this statement is true, they are only detailed as implementing the software of the activities. It is strongly advisable to give real signs (eg justifications, experiments, etc) of why these tools help the teaching of these topics. 2) This point is the cause of the previous point. Not a motivation or problem that clearly shows the need to use these tools for a language course. If the authors manage to find a clear and measurable motivation, point 1) can be resolved. Finally, the work fails to convince with its conclusion. Minor comments: 1) The work exceeds the maximum number required of pages (9 (> 8) pages). 2) In the conclusion, it is stated that with the use of Antlr on Android and the knowledge of formal languages, SIRI (Apple) & Google NOW can be equated. In my opinion, that affirmation is not true, because to resolve the activities use Google APIs, meaning that without Google's products, these activities can not be carried out. In summary, antlr and the knowledge of formal languages are not enough to build Google NOW. 3) It would be nice to use the DSLS canonic references instead of those used at work: @article {vandeursen: 2000: DLA: 352029.352035, Author = {van Deursen, Arie and Klint, Paul and Visser, Joost}, title = { Domain-Specific Languages: AN ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY}, Journal = {Sigplan not.}, ISSUE_DATE = {June 2000}, Volume = {35}, Number = {2000}, ISSN = { 0362-1340}, pages = {26--36}, numparages = {11}, url = {http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/352029.352035}, DOI = {10.1145 / 352029.352035}, acmid = {352035 }, Publisher = {ACM}, Address = {New York, NY, USA},} @Article {Mernik: 2005: DDL: 1118890.1118892, Author = {Mernik, Marjan and Heering, Jan and Sloane, Anthony M.}, Title = {When and How to Develop Domain-Specific Languages}, Journal = {ACM Comput. The article deals with the application of BPMN for the understanding of a business process in a mining company in Peru. The document is well structured and its reading is easy. Few wording errors are observed. In addition, its format is the demanded by Congress. In relation to the subject of the article, being an application of BPMN, it is not novel. From the case, I think it was possible to make a greater contribution, perhaps proposing a methodology to address the review of business processes, considering that the internal and external actors of the company, generally prioritize the optimization of their productive processes more than the review Of other processes. Finally and not least, the emphasis of the article is the review (audit) of the process with BPMN, moving away from the themes of Congress. Special emphasis could be given applications associated with Congress, such as BPMN requirements analysis, SOA implementation from BPMN, process monitoring with BAM and BPMN, etc. In some figures, although contractors are mentioned as an external entity, a

is not used to represent them and thus observe the interaction with the process under review. The future raised work is related to the results obtained from the improvements implemented from the analysis carried out in this work. I believe that rather to follow the improvements implemented it is convenient to follow up on how the revision of a processes is addressed in an environment that does not prioritize this type of task or is complex to perform them.

The article complies with the requirement of presenting a business experience in ICT applications with emphasis on mining, therefore, the evaluation will not be made in consideration any innovative proposal in a scientific article. This article describes a successful experience in the use of BPMN to model the business process of the engineering area and projects of a Peruvian mining company. A small and simple set of BPMN elements was used to model the business process. This experience is valid, but it is an ad hoc solution for the selected business process. The solution would have greater assessment if a small model had been presented that could be validated and that could solve a given set of business processes associated with mining. The article describes very well the SGBD for mobile, as well as some BD engines with non-relational technology known as Nosql, in a context of data storage in the cloud or cloud-computing. It makes a good comparison of the technical characteristics of some BD managers in this area (Table 3). It raises a methodology, apparently to define and perform an experiment that allows evaluating and comparing BD of this type, as defined in the title of the article. However, it only reaches a simple and qualitative comparison of components and other aspects as services (Table 4). There is no evidence of a quantitative and objective comparison, at the performance level and with data, transactions and processing times that really allow sustaining, as it does without these variables, which BD is more efficient with respect to another. The summary does not condition or identify the complete work. The conclusions are raised based on characteristics and not comparative performance tests. In short, it is a job from the point of view that would be a contribution if it formalized the methodology and described the quantitative application of an experimentation that really allows comparing the SGBD in a context of cloud-computing. It is suggested to complement with a controlled experiment with data and registration of test transactions and measure variables, obtain objective statistics that allow evaluating the performance of the BD mobile and Nosql systems, under conditions and clearly defined parameters and under the same environmental conditions (bandwidth, transaction tasks, data volume, equipment, etc).

The work presents a method for detecting fractures in well images. The work, in general, is very unconvincing for several reasons: 1.- It spends a LOT of space describing the fundamentals but not comparing and/or discussing with the state of the art There are MANY adaptive methods of image classification, and the problem that is presented has nothing different, except a different application 2.- The hypothesis is not clear, so the contribution of the work cannot be measured 3.- The detection method that is described only defines mathematical formulas for the geometric characterization of the fractures.This is a fairly unrobust procedure and even more so, the results evaluating the method are not convincing either in the standard metrics used (accuracy, error , ROC curve, etc.) 4.- The experimental methodology is very weak, neither does it compare the method with the state of the art, nor does it use standard metrics to analyze the precision/accuracy of the method.

This work shows the proposed procedure for the automatic detection of fractures in wells. The methodology looks new and interesting. The article shows the methodology well and is well written, but at the end of the article a better presentation of the results in real wells. The contribution of the article is not clear, first it indicates that it is automatic detection and in another part it indicates that it is the modification of the algorithm. It should improve the presentation of the results in real wells and compare it with what is desired and perhaps with results of applying other techniques.

As a first approach to the research area is pertinent, however, some more own work should be added to the paper.
