review.remarks: This article presents an interesting contribution by systematizing a process that is widely used in the development of information systems that require flexibility and adaptability to the changing environment.
review.text: This work is part of the business architecture area and proposes an interesting model for automating business rules to improve the flexibility of information systems applied to financial entities. The proposed model is aimed at decoupling the business logic of business rules The problem addressed in the article is adequately supported by the difficulties mentioned in the field of software projects and in the financial world The author could delve a little more into the experiences of project development in other areas and the relevance of business rules in the development of efficient information systems in the company The objective declared by the author            is to propose a methodology that makes it possible to make the operation of information systems in financial entities more flexible, which is generally adequately explained. The literature review is relevant to the issues addressed and the theories and models considered are appropriate to the objective that has been set. The analyzes associated with the concept of business rules and system architecture are related to the topic. The author should specify how the relationship between process modeling and the design and characterization of business rules is established. It is mentioned that they use the decision point tables, but these are not mentioned in detail or visually. The author should better support the choice of “Pipes and Filter” as the architecture model of the system. It would also be important to highlight if there are similar works carried out in other areas (since the author does not mention it) The methodological aspect of the work focuses on describing the process through which the definition of the software architecture is reached to automate the rules of business and the tools that were used in its development. This methodological approach is appropriate and is clearly associated with a case study application. The important contribution in this aspect is the detailed description of the process from the lifting of the rules to the design and development of the proposed application architecture. The author should make a summary table in which this process is represented in summary form. It is clear that the results of this work have the desired validity, since it is based on the use of models and tools already validated in the field of rule-based business platform design. The contribution of the work is important since it systematizes a process that is widely used in the development of information systems that are flexible and adaptable to the changing environment. However, these contributions are not clearly reflected in the conclusions, which is why it is suggested that the authors improve the conclusions, including significant contributions in methodological terms and contributions to the discipline in which the article is framed. The formal aspects of the work are satisfactory for the congress. There are minor details in the grammar such as in the first paragraph of the introduction that the letter U is missing. It is suggested to accept the article with minor modifications

The article is entitled "Software Architecture for the Automation of Business Rules in the Reception of Credit Requests in Financial Entities". The abstract indicates that the objective of the work is to propose an automation model of business rules that manages to decouple the business logic, however during the document no reference is made to any model.A methodology is presented in the section with its name, but it is not clear how said methodology allows to generate an automation model of business rules. The article lacks a logical sequence of sections that account for the explicit proposal cited in the abstract. In the System Architecture section, the architecture of a system is presented and aspects of the architecture are explained. However, In this section, it is also not possible to identify a model for automating business rules, taking into account that the article lacks hard work to improve the presentation of the same that allows understanding the proposal that is made, I suggest rejecting it. Below I send some observations that can be used to improve the work: Although the methodology used is explained in detail by phases, in none of them is reference made to the results achieved in its implementation in the case of the work that is exposed, that is, applied in an environment of financial entities. In the system architecture section, figure 5 and figure 6 are presented but they are not explained or contextualized within the document. This creates confusion. This section does not identify the application of the methodology set out in the previous section, in relation to the generated architecture. It should be clearly indicated how the architecture was achieved based on the methodology selected and explained in the Methodology section. In the introduction it is clear what is the proposal of the work presented. A paragraph must be structured that includes a definition of the objective of the work and the proposed solution that is made taking into account the title of the work. Some drafting errors must be corrected, such as: - In the abstract... For what purpose is it proposed...? - In the introduction... one of the main challenges of software engineering is not to generate...? - On page 3, the phase A term has a meaning for the business that must be understood and shared, is repeated twice. - On page 4 the word valido has an accent and in the last paragraph the accent is outside the word esta´. - At the end of page 5 the title is divided (widow). - It is suggested to improve the wording of the paragraph... The architectural vulnerability of the software systems has been observed in the provision of the services it provides with respect to the drafts... -The figures are not cited in the text, they are only indicated following figure, which constitutes problems both in form and edition of the article. Figures should be cited in the text, with the corresponding number in the title of the figure. - Figure 3 is not understood. The text is very small and it is not possible to identify the business process model referred to in the immediately preceding paragraph. - The last paragraph on page 6 is not understood and is spoken in the first person. The wording should be corrected. - In the Methodology section, reference is made to a project that has not been described before. It would be convenient to explain what the project referred to is about. In this section, the type of methodology referred to is not clear. It can be a research methodology or an architecture development methodology.

Throughout the article, the role of test automation within software testing and more generally in the assurance framework is exaggerated. A maturity model for software testing necessarily includes more aspects than automation. Automated cases will always coexist with manual cases and evaluations performed by people. As discussed in the article, automation is too general a concept, it can encompass the generation, execution, evaluation (for example: mutation, coverage criteria ) and validation (oracle problem). Although the motivation is clearly expressed in the introduction, references are needed to substantiate the statements made about the role of the test and the impact of automation on it. To say that automation allows performing the faster or cheaper testing is simplistic: this depends on the context The costs of generating automated test cases, the estimation of Information on future software evaluation and test case expiration, along with other factors, must be factored into the cost model to determine the desirability of automating a certain portion of the test. The section dedicated to software testing makes general definitions and walks through the history of testing since the mainframes. For a research article, I suggest making more specific definitions related to the focus of the study (experimental studies on test techniques, automation, test costs, maturity models). It would be appropriate to put the development of the maturity model after presenting the related work. The process to obtain the proposal of a maturity model for testing is not described. The development of the model must be linked to other existing maturity models (for example the Testing Maturity Model), establish connections with the accepted testing literature or standards (for example ISO 29119) and in general with software process models. The search string used is not specified. Not all models found should be classified as 'maturity models'. Some of the included models are clearly more general models, not addressing the problem of test automation. These differences should at least be discussed. The attributes used in table III are not explained, nor how to obtain the maturity level results. What does 'level of published reviews' mean? This concept is ambiguous. The description of this research process should be reinforced as it is key to obtaining the 'adolescent' level result.

review.remarks: The article is out of order. The research proposal is not clear and the scope they propose covers several fronts, possibly the reason why the topics they address are out of order.
review.text: The work is entitled "Current maturity of software test automation development". The document shows a series of sections that account for a work carried out in terms of literature review and some approaches to a proposal to restructure a scale of particular maturity levels for the test automation process.However , the work lacks a logical structure that allows determining if its contribution or main objective is in the literature review or in the proposal of new maturity levels for the testing process. It is recommended to make a complete review of the information presented and possibly restructure the document presented. The report of this review was divided into sections, in order to provide suggestions that allow improving the Section -Systematic review It is important that the authors review the fact of using a systematic review method that is not yet published. There have been several published, tested, and recognized methods for software engineering. They should justify the selection of the method proposed by Serna M. identified with the number [16] in the work. It is essential to explain the validation that is done regarding the peer review of the articles, since it is not clear how a peer review of the published articles can be accessed in order to validate them and how a validation process is carried out from of said information, taking into account the number of revisions that would have to be made for each article found (978). Test automation Although, in the work a proposed model is reported to evaluate the maturity of the software test automation process. The model as such is not described. The article is limited to presenting a reference scale associated with the maturity of a human being. Therefore, it is essential that the article indicates several aspects to consider the structuring and definition of a model. Among the most important aspects to consider are: 1. A scientific and formal justification on which the authors of the work are based to propose the maturity model and the selection of the maturity levels of a human being as a point of comparison with a possible maturity level of the test automation process. 2. Formal justification of why not to use the CMMI model and the structure of maturity levels proposed in it to evaluate the test automation process. The foregoing, taking into account that the maturity model defines an appropriate maturity scale to evaluate processes in software engineering. In other words, why is it necessary to rethink those maturity levels for the test automation process and propose a new scale based on the maturity of a human being? 3. At the research level, how are maturity levels characterized in terms of test automation? Although the article characterizes each level indicating the possible characteristics in which the test automation process is, it does not indicate how said characterization was determined, nor is a related formal and scientific justification shown. Related work The work presents a systematic review, under which it is possible to identify work related to the area of study, in this case test automation or maturity levels for test automation. However, the authors present the systematic review separately from the related work section, when it appears that the studies selected as related work should be part of the analysis of the results of the systematic review. In addition, the systematic review allows the identification of research gaps or niches (research opportunities) to determine a work area with a specific problem and, from there, propose a possible solution to said problem. In this case, the article presents the systematic review as an additional work and subsequent to the proposal of maturity levels for the test automation process. Likewise, the authors show the selection of some related works, it is understood that they are related to test automation, notwithstanding the first Michael Grottke, they indicate precisely that it does not focus on the subject to be treated in the work they present but on a Statistical proposal of test automation. Therefore it would not enter as related work. Software Test Automation Development Maturity To compare the test automation process and its maturity levels, the authors present Table 3. It indicates that the first column lists the traditional stages of a test automation process. testing process. It is necessary to indicate under what methodology these stages are selected as traditional or to have a reference as justification for the selection of these and not other stages. In this section there is no clear explanation of the determination of maturity levels at each stage. It is essential to have a description of the research analysis carried out, which results in the definition of the maturity level of each of the stages of the testing process. The table is not a sufficient explanation for the analysis, since it only reports the results. At this point, if what is sought is to propose a new maturity scale for the test process or test automation, the most convenient thing is to validate said proposed scale with a case study. In this work, although the authors show a table where they seem to determine that the maturity level is "adolescent", it is not possible to understand in what context the test automation process is being evaluated. At least one case should be contextualized where it is indicated: region, time, type of projects or companies and methodology used to evaluate the test automation process. The foregoing is the basis for justifying that in a given context the test automation process is at X level of maturity (of the proposed scale). Arguing, in addition, the criteria that were taken into account to assign said level of maturity.

The authors present an approach to solve resource-constrained project scheduling problems (RCPSP) through an artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm. The idea seems relevant to the problem faced. However, it is important make the following improvements to the document: - Clearly establish that the application of ABC in RCPSP is something that has not been done before, if not, add a comparative analysis of the proposed solution against similar ones - The link http:/ /www.om-db.wi.tum.de/psplib/datasm.html is broken. Replace with a link that is not. - In the tables it is not clear what the Makespan is. It is the duration of the "canonical schedule " for that problem? Is it the duration of the optimal theoretical schedule? Is it the duration of the schedule of the best algorithm for this problem? Is it the duration obtained by the ABC-RCPSP algorithm? Explain this precisely - It would be advisable to have a brief quantitative description of the performance of algorithm in terms of time vs problem size.

review.remarks: The work presented to Infonor - Chile, meets the following expectations:
review.text: The work presented to Infonor - Chile, meets the following expectations: 1. It carries out an accurate bibliographic discussion 2. It incorporates a novel hybrid search algorithm 3. The results obtained with scheduling with restrictions using the algorithm (limited resources ) shows encouraging results.

The work presents the proposal for a quality model for Internet banking software. The work has several weaknesses: - The objective of the work is not clearly specified, and it is described differently in several sections. - The research methodology is not clear --> The constituent elements of the proposal (Dromey, ISO 25010, MOSCA...) The motivation for why they were selected is not described, nor is the bias that this selection may have in the model --> The use of a Research/Action methodology is described, but the phenomenon that has been studied to consolidate the model is not described --> The theoretical framework sections also seem to be biased, and describes the sources that gave rise to the selection of references Other minor comments: - The translation of the abstract into English should be reviewed - The bibliography of software quality, comes out of textbooks, and can be updated - The scope e towards quality tributes, is both introduced as part of the methodological framework, and exposed as conclusions. It can't be both. By directing the research towards owasp, the construct is oriented towards security attributes, therefore the conclusion: "In the same sense, it is established that the quality of a system for Internet Banking must consider security as a mandatory point, in addition to the functionality" It is a result of the design of your research, and cannot be extracted from the work. - Reference 6 and 11 are the same.

The article goes through definitions of quality, software quality and quality models. Some models are treated first in a preliminary section and others after the theoretical analysis, I suggest re-organizing the presentation of concepts. In my In my opinion, the concepts of quality model and conceptual model are not equivalent, although they are treated together in the introduction.In the second section several models are presented, but the relationships between them and what is the criterion for having them is not clearly established taken into account in this line of research. There are multiple proposals for software quality models and specific models for the web. On the other hand, the OWASP guidelines are relevant to the security of web applications, they are not a quality model. I suggest exposing the theoretical analysis (which includes basic definitions of quality) before the description and justification of the considered models On the other hand, concepts could be added / attributes / specific quality models in the context of banking systems. In my opinion, devoting so much space to defining the concept of electronic banking, internet banking and then mobile banking is not necessary in the current state of the art and public knowledge of these concepts. I suggest focusing on the research objectives of this particular work. The descriptions of the DESMET methodological framework and the research-action methodology are very brief. It is necessary to establish the objectives of the research beforehand. The conceptual models obtained are the main result of the work. More readable notations should be used (I also suggest putting extended information as an annex to the article or on the web). It should also be explained how these models were validated, so that they are reliable if they are used to define ontologies or used in later works.

The authors propose the analysis of the data through the CRISP-DM methodology, but it is not used in the development. The authors make use of the WEKA tool and the algorithms that said tool has implemented. Perhaps it would be better to think of a proprietary algorithm for this type of data to be analyzed, or some mechanism where the expert does not have to mark the shapes of the eddies in the images to be processed.

The article presents the development of a case study of pattern recognition to identify ocean eddies through satellite images. The article is well written and structured. Its presentation follows a logical sequence of development. In what corresponds to the state of the art, methods for the detection of "eddies" are mentioned. Except for the case of neural networks, quantitative results obtained with each method are not mentioned. For this reason, it is not possible to establish a comparison of the performance obtained versus other methods referenced in the state of the art. The part of understanding and exploring the data is weak.

The article reflects on the current state and possible projections of formal methods in software development. Although the idea of making such a reflection has interesting potential, the article falls short in two key aspects: 1. There are many assertions made in the document that do not have bibliographic citations to support them, nor do they follow from a logical deduction from previous premises.This significantly undermines the validity of the arguments presented. 2. All the assertions presented in the document that, according to the interpretation, the authors want to present as their own, are, in fact, widely known problems in the area of formal methods In summary, the article does not provide assertions with sufficient evidence or a solid line of argument, nor does it provide assertions For these reasons , I consider that the article is not suitable for publication.

review.remarks: The report is an interesting "dissemination" work, however, as a "research" report it is limited.

It seems to me that as a "dissemination" work it is very interesting, but as a "research" report it is limited.

The article presents a proposal for Repairing Inconsistencies in Data Warehouses using constraints that make semantic sense. Priority and safe constraints are proposed, in addition to using heuristics previously defined in "Repairing dimensions hierarchies under inconsistent reclassification" to computation of r-repairs. The examples used to explain the proposal are clear. The article is well written.

It is a difficult work to catalog, it presents a topic usually associated with deductive databases (repair), where there must be integrity rules or constraints that have been violated, adapted to the topic of inconsistency produced by new facts in a DW files that don't scale correctly to their dimensions.This is usually dealt with in this area by using Slowly Changing Dimensions (SCD), something that strangely isn't named in the article.Still, and assuming the problem really exists and it has applicability, it is presented very superficially, and it finally ends in an informal proposal that is not rigorously described as an algorithm itself.It seems to me that it is a proposal that is still in a very initial state and whose problematic does not manage to convince me as such.

The article presents an approach by Genetic Algorithms (GA) to solve light diffusion equations in turbid media. It is indicated that one of the main advantages of GA over traditional methods is the elimination of noise from the resulting images. However, it is not very clear why this is, nor is it evident that a quantitative method was used to determine the absence of noise. It is imperative that the authors solve this problem to give the article sufficient strength.

The article shows a study of the application of Genetic Algorithms to solve a system of equations in optical images for tumor detection and follow-up of cancer treatments. The work is well written and has a high level of technical detail. However , does not explicitly show what its main contributions are.In this sense, it would be convenient to expand the Introduction Section to provide the reader with a detail of the main contributions of the work and also include in this section (or in a section of Related Works or State of the Art ) a greater detail of other previous works that are related to the authors' proposal In the field of application of Genetic Algorithms for solving systems of equations, this work does not present a novel contribution, since there are several previous works oriented to this type of solution Regarding image analysis and pattern recognition, there are previous works that Genetic Algorithms are already used for this type of proposal, such as Dourdan, 2015. It would be convenient to have had a comparison with other Machine Learning methods that have been widely applied to image recognition, such as k-means or PCA. Minors: - In Figure 10, the AG Solution series is not well displayed due to the number of plotted points. - Last paragraph of Conclusions. "...the advantage of working with heuristics like genetic algorithms..." should be "...the advantage of working with heuristics like genetic algorithms...". - Last paragraph of Conclusions. The references to Pattern Recognition works are old 1997, I think there are more up-to-date references and there are more works where various machine learning techniques are applied for pattern recognition, from supervised to unsupervised methods.

Despite being a well-explored problem, the review of the state of the art and related works is limited. The results are presented through images of the molecular structure. It is convenient to present performance measures and a description in abstract formal notation of the algorithm used .

review.remarks: The article addresses a topic of great relevance for the development of open governments. However, it is quite general in its review and its generalizations are not possible for the government as a whole. It is accepted with changes that should be made by the authors due to review.
review.text: Open data in Chile This work analyzes in a general way an issue that has acquired real relevance in governments worldwide, open data. The problem addressed in the article is adequately supported by the existing needs to provide data to evaluate transparency and public interest. An investigation is carried out applied to the main government web platforms in Chile. The objective is declared by the author and establishes that the state of open data in Chile is presented and a diagnosis of the main sites and tools provided by the state to improve transparency and enhance citizen participation The bibliographic review is relevant to the topic but quite general The model used to measure the quality of data on the web is chosen without justifying through an analysis that establishes its efficiency compared to other models The review of the concept of open data is minimal and is not present in the review carried out as this issue has been addressed in different countries and the results they have obtained. The authors should further delve into the concept of open data at the government level for transparency and the public interest and better support this division in the literature. The methodological aspect of the work focuses on using the 5-star model and describing a general classification based on this model. Although this methodological approach is adequate and is clearly associated with the subject, it does not present propositions to be evaluated (research questions or hypotheses to be tested). The diagnosis is basic and general based on four variables that allow each platform to be classified. The author should also establish a categorization of what the study subjects are (the government of Chile is mentioned but there are only four platforms out of the total number of platforms owned by the government). In this sense, it should refer to transversal central service platforms (since it does not analyze local governments at any time). This work is based on the use of a diagnostic model already validated in the literature , however its application is limited and, in my opinion, it does not allow generalize to the government as a whole. The contribution of the work is important since it presents relevant information in the process of reaching what is open government. However, the generalizability of their results is questionable as it is limited to four variables and four websites. The main contributions of the article are not clearly reflected in the conclusions and it is suggested that the authors improve them by including aspects relevant to the subject evaluated (the websites), the contributions to the study of open government in Chile and to recognize the limitations that this study has. study. The formal aspects of the work are satisfactory for the congress.

The document presents a study of the state of the art of the techniques and methods that the corpus of research offers for the treatment of requirements in agile environments. The theme is totally current and I agree with the authors that little has been done still and it is a field of exploitation. There are, however, two comments that I would like to pass on to the reviewers. The first is that it is not clear why they have not done a systematic review of the literature in a more formal way. The justification that they offer does not make sense to me. seems convincing. On the other hand, I would like them to have developed a little more in future work. After a good job it is not clear to me what they have learned to put it into practice in their future research.

In this work an exploratory proposal is made on a profile of adequacy of software requirements elicitation techniques. The work is an extension of a previous work. It is recommended to improve some aspects of this manuscript, such as: -Describe in more detail the previous work on which this paper is based and mention the differences and new content -Consistency between the terms requirements and requirements, on page 3 the term requirements is used -As far as possible, maintain terms in Spanish. -Add accent on "only" as long as it refers to "only". -Correct "Lo" by "Los" end of page 4, after ref. 15., add accent to "compare", on same page, correct final "four" page 6. -Correct text alignment in first paragraphs of both columns on page 10, the first paragraph of the second column should be in the first column.

Article focused on requirements elicitation techniques. As a general comment, in subject+verb type sentences, it is not necessary to put a comma after the subject (e.g., in the introduction section "the software requirements education, is that ...", in the background "software engineering is a discipline .."). Regarding Table 2, it would be convenient for the authors to put the rows of the table in the same order they are listed in. A couple of questions come to mind: How is the contextual situation of a project constructed? (lock) Although I imagine it will be a similar process, how is the suitability profile of the techniques? (key) Does it consist of putting the graph of the technique by dimension in flat form? If you could clarify with some phrase. For example, indicate that the dimensions have a number (indicate it in Table 4 for example), to later see clearly the graphs in Figure 4. The same for the factors and Fig. to 3.

review.remarks: The article provides a review of a growing technology, but there is no experimental work that provides new knowledge.
review.text: The article describes a comparison of two tools used in big data applications. The content can be followed without major inconveniences and follows a logical order. However, the following shortcomings were identified: - The tests carried out are carried out based on a data set (graph) of reduced size, contravening the fact that it is trying to compare tools used with big data - The test case for its solution requires a lot of computation, but it is not an example of big data This is inferred from the fact that the data set is a graph of 31 vertices and 82 nodes - In the conclusions it is stated that it was detected that in Chile the level of knowledge regarding the problems generated by big data is meager. This is supported by two references, but there is no own work that supports this statement, such as a survey of the national market.

The article is adequately written, except for some accent problems (implemented, used, ...) The tools used, as well as the implemented algorithms are adequately described. The only criticism is in their implementation , carried out on a single machine (probably due to a problem of resources), something that detracts from what has been done, considering that we are talking about techniques designed to be used in a distributed way (where their maximum use should be) . , I think it is a well-presented work, valuable in the discussion of the limitations of Hadoop vs Giraph, and whose results are interesting to learn about and debate in the congress.

There are important contributions, the combination of Digital image processing in geology and specifically in the identification of Fractures in Well Images is a novel contribution (in my opinion). A fundamental contribution to the work has to do with the the proposal of the automatic method of identification of baselines and parameterization of fractures, based on image processing techniques and a voting process implemented by means of the Hough transform. More observations are included in the attached file.

This paper shows the proposed procedure for Automatic Identification of Fractures in well images. The methodology looks novel and interesting. The article shows the methodology well and is well written. Metrics were added to measure the effectiveness of the algorithm. This work was presented at INFONOR 2014 and the current wording is the same, which although it is true is good, it has the same small errors as in the previous article. Therefore, you should review it again. Although it now shows metrics for measure the result it is not indicated how effective this system is compared to the one used before. You should improve figures 12 and 15, where you show the metrics. Figure 2, left is not distinguishable. It is missing to include a reference to figure 11 in the text.

review.remarks: In case the work is accepted, a detailed review is recommended to the editor (recommendations were given to the authors in the review). Likewise, it is recommended to review the bibliographic references since there are 3 references associated only with Tool Suites and 3 references to give a definition within the article, in both cases that could be used for references to previous work in the area of study.
review.text: The article presents an evaluation of genetic algorithm techniques for online reverse engineering of software products. Most of the work is focused on presenting and explaining in detail Software Product Line Engineering (PSLI) and the application of Reverse Engineering on this paradigm. The explanation associated with ILPS and Reverse Engineering is detailed in the Introduction of the article, even for reverse engineering two more definitions are given for the same concept. However, in the same section there is no reference some to Genetic Algorithms that is also part of this work. In general, the work is interesting but lacks a high innovative impact with respect to works associated with Genetic Algorithms. In the Results and Evaluation section, a detail of Results Tables is shown, without However, the discussion and explanation of results is only delivered in 1 paragraph. A clearer explanation would be expected regarding the s meaning of each of the columns of the table and corresponding results. In the references section there are 3 references [11], [12], [13] to establish a definition, it would be expected to have more references to similar works, perhaps a Related Work section could be included. Minors. -- In general, it is recommended to review the wording of some sentences. Just as an example I recommend reviewing the last sentence of the Summary. Another example is the ACKNOWLEDGMENTS paragraph. -- In figure 2 the series "With LPS" is not displayed correctly in Black/White printing -- On p. 8 penultimate paragraph there is a "." which is from the previous paragraph on a blank line. -- Table 2 has a larger and apparently different Font format than the rest of the article.

review.remarks: Improving the description of the results and generating a slightly deeper evaluation, the article is publishable.
review.text: The document describes a way to apply current computer engineering techniques to the problem of software product lines. The document is well explained, but it is considered necessary to deepen the results and evaluation. The work described is interesting already that applies Genetic Algorithms to a specific problem, but lacks innovative impact in the domain. It is recommended to review the wording (in general) of the document.

This work shows an interactive visual environment for exploratory analysis of models in data mining. There is a work called 'Augmented decision tree model using self-organizing maps', accepted in 2014 in Ingeniare magazine, which shows a methodology very similar to the one proposed in this work. In this regard, this work has figures from the previous work that it does not refer to. In fact, figure 1 of this work presents it graphically differently from figure 1 of Ingeniere's work, being the same model. Even when it seems that the surveys are applied to different students (not specified), the results and sentences are very similar to the previous project. Therefore, the contribution or difference of this work with the previous one should be specified much more clearly, if is that it exists.

The article is interesting, it covers many terms in depth. Some observations are: - There should be between 5 and 10 keywords. - Change the word "entonro" - Remove the accent from "this mode" - No use color according to papers Infonor instructions - Change word "Dendrogram" - Review "panning"

review.remarks: This paper has a special affinity with the business applications workshop.
review.text: The article is especially valid as a data center implementation guide. Its theoretical level is not relevant, however its applicability makes it of interest. The article is well written and documented. It must be insisted that it is of a case and this case is fully developed following the proposed TIA standards as a reference.

review.remarks: It is considered interesting that it be accepted for the INFONOR congress in the BUSINESS APPLICATIONS WORKSHOP

It is an applied research work, original and a very interesting application in a company. Suggested improvements: Missing Incorporate a section of related works. Also, measure the degree of effectiveness of its implementation, in a section of analysis of results and tests.

The article is interesting, both in the application of control theory and mobile robotics. It requires a complete review of writing, spelling and punctuation. I am attaching the revised file with some annotations to improve the presentation, however Authors must re-review the document completely.

this paper applies an advanced algorithm to gait control, but it seems that more explanations are needed for a clearer understanding and comparison with other traditional algorithms. The math is very well stated but I was unable to see the advantages or purpose of that math regarding gait control.Also, it is not clear for the reader how fast or slow is the calculation time regarding task time.

The authors follow the SEMMA and CRISP-DM methodologies for the development of the project. Throughout the paper the authors describe the phase of the methodology, the work carried out and the results obtained in that phase, except in the data mining phase (and clustering) that the authors postpone the description of the work and the results to section 5 of the paper. This makes the structure of the paper not entirely clear. Another thing is the simplification of the variables to take into account when carrying out the data mining process, since it would be necessary to take into account other aspects related to the client, the receiver, ...

The article deals with a data mining process aimed at describing groups for the analysis of money laundering in the banking sector. It uses the CRISP-DM process as a methodological reference and follows it with some dedication. As for the substance : details too many aspects that are related to the descriptive part of the financial topic and the bank in particular where the development of the work is circumscribed It also emphasizes obtaining the mineable view, which is fine, but neglects the generation of the data mining model, specifically not It does not show the clustering model, nor does it show the levels of coverage and confidence in each rule of each cluster, it does not perform a statistical analysis about the patterns, and it does not observe a validation of the model and patterns obtained, the latter being the greatest weakness of the work. In reference to the form: there are many spelling and writing errors, excessive length of some paragraphs and writing of some topics that are they should summarize, they also write in the fourth person and in some parts in the future tense, they should standardize the writing in the 3rd person and present tense, except in the conclusions that can occupy the past tense. exceeds no. of pages set maximum. Finally, it presents little bibliography (only 4) and also no references anywhere. It is an article that can be accepted but requires a profound re-ordering in terms of form, and fundamentally in relation to the data mining model, its analysis and exhaustive evaluation, as well as its results.

In this work, a systematic review of the literature on the subject of software requirements management in small companies is carried out. The work is relevant for the community given the little information that exists on this subject. As minor corrections, it is recommended to work more the results section adding the synthesis of the review as well as discussing the results according to the research question posed, finally it is recommended to remove the reference that appears in the abstract.

As for the general aspects, three things: 1) the authors should be consistent with the nomenclature used: mainly requirements vs. requirements: please use only one of the two denominations, but do not mix at will 2) Secondly, small settings vs. small and medium-sized companies. If you go to the definition given by the SEI, you will see that it is not the same, the concept of small setting being broader. In this case I think that the authors are referring to small companies. 3) As a third comment, general, check the punctuation marks, very long sentences. In the abstract, the authors indicate that they are going to offer a work proposal for small environments. I cannot find that proposal of works in the article. Also, it is better not to put references in the abstract. In the introduction, second paragraph, it appears "since this allows to guarantee FROM ..." an UNTIL SUCH THING is expected... In the section system review process topic, it is not necessary to make a subsection, it does not make much sense to divide something into a single section. In the systematic review phases grant, they first say there are 3 steps and then they call it phases. Which of the two is it??? The names given to the phases do not coincide with those of the following sections, nor with those of Figure 1. Figure 1 does not contribute anything. In the planning section, words like "above" are not very valid in written language. Likewise, in the planning they include paragraphs that justify the reason for the SMEs, this is already out of context here. They also indicate that the objective of the review is to find models, methodologies, proposals or processes related to requirements management. Well, this is what they are expected to obtain in the results of the systematic review, and this hardly appears (it only appears a list of methodologies and little else). They also mix improvement of software processes with improvement of requirements management. Then they indicate that the results are measured by the number of proposals... when previously they have said otherwise. The sections of the review do not faithfully follow those of Kitchenham, and Biolchini. Also in the part of "search string" appears "is that", which in written language does not look good. The list of sources, why does it appear in the search string grant? In the revision part, Table 3 and Figure 2 are redundant, if one more column is added to the table, indicating the corresponding percentage, we have the same effect. In the Review part, YOU CANNOT DECIDE TO INCLUDE ONLY THE FIRST 20, so why do we do the systematic review???? Also a single grant???. What are the 20 items you selected? Where are they referenced? The same happens with Figure 4 and Table 4. Regarding the Results, it is to be assumed that references 18 to 29 are the primary articles??? In these results they only indicate justifications related to requirements management, but nothing related to what they indicate in the objective of their systematic review. Based on a reference from 2007, number 24, they indicate that it had not dealt with the management of requirements in small companies. I only indicate a doctoral thesis from the UPM of November 2013, entitled Metamodel for the improvement of the requirements management process, whose author is Ariel E. Serrano Rico and Director Jose A. Calvo-Manzano, so that you can see that there are things on requirements management. This is also the only site where they indicate a series of methodologies. This, which is supposed to be one of the expected results, only appears in two lines of the results section. Then it adds a series of key factors, and conditions that seem to appear by themselves, without any reference and that are also not the objective that the authors say regarding the review they have made.

The article is easy to read, especially in its first half. Then, there are writing and editing errors that affect the understanding of what has been done (PostgrSQL instead of PostgresSQL, with has instead of contains, ...).In addition, steps are detailed, which fall into irrelevant details, such as indicating that this or that tool must be installed, without going into the really important aspects, especially in the implementation of the middle coupling (where, it is not detailed that it was implemented at the level of the SABD and that at an external level). They no longer only have the implementation of the algorithm as an independent variable, but also the SABD to be used. In spite of the above, I think that the work is worthy of being presented, in order to show, in particular, the different alternatives . rnatives for integrating Data Mining algorithms with Database Management Systems.

review.remarks: Another question to the authors, why do you use two DBMS? PostgreSQL for weak coupling. And Oracle for medium and strong coupling.
review.text: The article shows the empirical results of the integration (coupling) of the a priori algorithm in a DBMS. They indicate that the exposed work is based on the work of Agrawal & Shim, this work is from the year 1996, in this regard, right? Are there more recent works?, Can I choose another more recent work?, Why choose this work? Why this approach? The introduction lacks references that allow the work to be substantiated as a contribution a little closer to something scientific. For example "There are some focused investigations"....which ones? The work is written more as a technical experiment, than as a congress article. The time and effort in carrying out the tests is valued.

review.remarks: I recommend improving the article specifically on the proposed solution, for which no specific evidence of development is given.
review.text: Form problems identified: - Figure 7 is not clear in its content. - Figure 5 and 6 do not contribute to the work developed. - The transaction process should be numbered. - Table should be Table, in addition to table 2 , 3 and 4 are not legible They should be rewritten - Page 3 the text of the word Samsung is not in the same type of font - Figure 8 has no title - The spelling should be corrected and improved (conclusions). Background problems: - Section 3.1.2 is not directly related to the problem raised - The description of the architectures and modes of use of NFC does not contribute to the solution presented - In section 4.1 mention is made of the machine virtual Dalvik, however, from Android Lollipop version upwards, ART is used and not Dalvik - Table 6 does not provide the work developed - The work developed uses 8 of 11 pages in introduction and technologies, however, only 1 page is used to display l as evidences. - Some indicators are proposed, however, no evidence is given of the values obtained. - Figures 10, 11 and 12 show screenshots of the application?, however, they do not indicate in detail how the technologies are applied in Android. - Lack of evidence of the described application, in particular from the area of software engineering.

This work makes a presentation of works related to the control of access of people to certain facilities. It describes some technologies that can be used to implement this control. However, it remains in a proposal that tries to adapt solutions to a local problem. More development of models and theoretical support is needed to present an original solution, which contributes to progress in this area. Other Sections."

Just lousy formatting, writing also leaves a lot to be desired, blurry figures, tables scanned from somewhere with no reference. Content doesn't exist. This must be one of the worst articles I've ever seen ,

review.text: The document describes an exploratory work in the development of a software application in the area of medical informatics, specifically in HIS (Hospital Information System) systems. The proposal is interesting but the document indicates that it is incipient work, This is not understood, given that the proposed architecture and the project methodology are described, but a test scenario or a specific validation case is not described. Likewise, the description of a software resulting from the project is not observed in the document, and from the title of the article and the abstract, the description of some software proposal is expected.

The paper aims to offer a vision of the use of EVA tools in the different environments of higher education subjects (face-to-face, non-face-to-face and blended). The idea of the paper is clear, but I have a hard time finding the research justification for it. The results obtained are quite biased and the proposal is not defined as a clear experiment. I think it would have been interesting to be more rigorous when considering it. There are also some aspects, such as, for example, the fact that the list of selected evas that is not justified, where did you get that list? Is it closed? For all these reasons, I advocate not accepting this job.

The paper is well written and easy to read. It fits the format of the event. State of the art well planned and reviewed. The weak rejection is because it does not agree with the topics of interest of INFONOR's work , see list at http://www.infonor-chile.cl/page/organizacion#areas-interes The paper should be presented at an Engineering Education event, for which it is suggested that the results obtained be comparable with subjects without tutorials and analyze the learning results achieved by students in control and experimental groups.
